Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It XXXX Concern at XXXX, Equifax and XXXX, I am writing to express my deep concern over XXXX, Equifax, XXXX furthermore known as " the XXXX bureaus '' failure to investigate my mailed-in disputes, resulting in a violation of my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). I have received a response letter from " the XXXX bureaus '' indicating that my mailed-in dispute request " does not appear to have been sent directly by [ me ] or to be authorized by [ me ], '' which is not only inaccurate but also constitutes a failure to investigate my disputes as required by the FCRA. 
Let me be clear : I have never used a credit repair company or any XXXX party to submit disputes on my behalf. I am the sole author and sender of each dispute I submit to " the XXXX bureaus '', and I have provided notarized documentation along with identification to prove my identity. There should be no ambiguity regarding the legitimacy of my mailed-in disputes. 
According to FCRA 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), if a consumer disputes the accuracy or completeness of information in their credit report, the XXXX XXXX XXXX must conduct a free reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate. " The XXXX bureaus '' refusal to investigate my mailed-in disputes on the grounds that they " do not appear to have been sent directly by [ me ] '' is a clear violation of this provision. 
" The XXXX bureaus '' ongoing practice of sending letters that delay the investigation process by questioning the authenticity of my disputes is unacceptable and constitutes a significant breach of my rights under the FCRA. By failing to conduct a timely and thorough investigation into my disputes, " the XXXX bureaus '' is causing unnecessary delays, which impacts my creditworthiness and financial well-being. 
I demand that " the XXXX bureaus '' promptly address this issue by : XXXX. Opening and investigating every mailed-in dispute that I submit upon receipt. 
XXXX. Stopping the practice of sending letters that question the legitimacy of my disputes without valid grounds. 
XXXX. Complying with FCRA regulations that mandate the investigation of disputes submitted by consumers. 
If " the XXXX bureaus '' fails to comply with these demands and continues to violate my rights under the FCRA, I will take further action, including but not limited to filing complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and pursuing legal remedies to enforce my rights. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. I expect a response confirming that " the XXXX bureaus '' has corrected its practices and will properly investigate my mailed-in disputes in accordance with FCRA requirements. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit card
Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Problem during payment process
Consumer complaint narrative:
Recently I retired, at some point I was not able to continue making payments on my PayPal account. Prior to this situation, I had opened a crypto currently account through their site. I liked the idea because I could make purchases in small amounts. 

However, now that XXXX cant my payments as I previously did, I am unable to access my account in any form or fashion. Each and every time, I try to access the account, I always receive the following messages : something went wrong, please try again ; please enter three email accounts associated with your account ; reset your password, however, when I choose this option, it circles back to enter your email address and we will send a reset link. 

I try this every few months, only to end up in the same vicious circle. I do know that at one point I was past due with a balance of roughly {$220.00} odd dollars. However, I do believe that there was enough funds in the crypto account that would have allowed me to liquidate the account and bring my account current. However, since I was locked out of my PayPal account, I was denied the ability to use this option. 

I dont know, it I believe this practice from PayPal has to be illegal in some aspect.

I would appreciate any assistance I can get. I dont think they should be allowed to hold my funds hostage. As previously mentioned, I do believe there was enough money in the crypto account to have gotten my account back on track, but they denied me this option.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Product: Credit card
Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative: Over a period of about a week starting XX/XX/XXXX, someone began making large transactions using my credit card at XXXX, XXXX XXXX, and other stores, adding up to about {$26000.00}. When I discovered this on XX/XX/XXXX, I called chase and identified the fraudulent charges, and they removed the charges from my account and issued me a new card, so I thought everything was fine. Over the next couple of months they occasionally called me to ask for details to assist in their fraud investigation, but I couldn't think of anything unusual that happened that could've explained exactly how someone could have gained access to my card. Then on XX/XX/XXXX, they posted a letter to my account claiming that I had " received benefit from the transactions '' and was therefore responsible for them, and immediately added the {$26000.00} of charges back to my credit card. When I tried to call and ask what this meant they were unable to provide a satisfactory answer ; the only useful thing they said was that on the date of the first fraudulent transaction, I had apparently given them a phone call telling them that it was a valid use of my credit card, but this was completely untrue : I have no memory of such a call, and my call history shows XXXX calls made or received by me on that date. When I told them this, they said they would reopen the case, but they refused to remove the charges from my account because " that's not their procedure for reopened cases ''. This is especially annoying because the {$26000.00} of charges put me well over my credit limit, rendering me unable to use the card unless I paid a significant portion of them off ; the fraud department told me that I should be able to request a temporary credit limit increase from customer service, but when I called customer service they claimed this wasn't possible and that I just had to apply for a normal credit limit increase. I did ask to do that just as a potential temporary solution, but there's no guarantee that will go through or that it will be a large enough increase where I can avoid paying off the charges. The abruptness of charging my card with such a huge amount and their inability to provide me with prompt assistance has left me feeling extremely stressed and frustrated.

Product: Student loan
Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been faithfully paying on my large student loan balance for many years and have been a dedicated XXXX employee since XXXX and local government employee since XXXX. I made my XXXX payment for the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program in XX/XX/XXXX and requested loan forgiveness, and a forbearance to not require additional XXXX XXXX  monthly payments until the forbearance is applied and PSLF application is processed and loans discharged. 

Both DOE/Federal Student Aid ( FSA ) and the loan servicer MOHELA have proven incompetent and processing this request. The account has been bounced back and forth from MOHELA to Student Aid and I have received a variety of emails about " loan transitions '' but nothing substantive about my requests for temporary forbearance and loan forgiveness, and my account currently reflects almost 90 days past due. I should not be required to make payments while the government sorts out how it will handle my loan account and processes my paperwork. 

This issue continues to cause financial and emotional distress for me and my family and I have lost countless hours having to deal with this mess created by this incompetent company. I have filed multiple complaints with MOHELA, DOE/FSA , Congressman XXXX XXXX office, and XXXX  and thus far the issue remains unresolved. I am also a class member of the putative class action litigation pending in Missouri against MOHELA and other defendants related to their incompetent handling of student loan accounts. 

Please contact MOHELA to ensure a forbearance is applied to my account and ensure my loan forgiveness application is processed ASAP.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

I have received a response letter from " the XXXX bureaus '' indicating that my mailed-in dispute request " does not appear to have been sent directly by [ me ] or to be authorized by [ me ], '' which is not only inaccurate but also constitutes a failure to investigate my disputes as required by the FCRA. 
Let me be clear : I have never used a credit repair company or any third party to submit disputes on my behalf. I am the sole author and sender of each dispute I submit to " the XXXX bureaus '', and I have provided notarized documentation along with identification to prove my identity. There should be no ambiguity regarding the legitimacy of my mailed-in disputes. 
According to FCRA 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), if a consumer disputes the accuracy or completeness of information in their credit report, the credit reporting agency must conduct a free reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate. " The XXXX bureaus '' refusal to investigate my mailed-in disputes on the grounds that they " do not appear to have been sent directly by [ me ] '' is a clear violation of this provision. 
" The XXXX bureaus '' ongoing practice of sending letters that delay the investigation process by questioning the authenticity of my disputes is unacceptable and constitutes a significant breach of my rights under the FCRA. By failing to conduct a timely and thorough investigation into my disputes, " the XXXX bureaus '' is causing unnecessary delays, which impacts my creditworthiness and financial well-being. 
I demand that " the XXXX bureaus '' promptly address this issue by : XXXX. Opening and investigating every mailed-in dispute that I submit upon receipt. 
XXXX. Stopping the practice of sending letters that question the legitimacy of my disputes without valid grounds. 
XXXX. Complying with FCRA regulations that mandate the investigation of disputes submitted by consumers. 
If " the XXXX bureaus '' fails to comply with these demands and continues to violate my rights under the FCRA, I will take further action, including but not limited to filing complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and pursuing legal remedies to enforce my rights. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. I expect a response confirming that " the XXXX bureaus '' has corrected its practices and will properly investigate my mailed-in disputes in accordance with FCRA requirements. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Information belongs to someone else
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you as a last resort after multiple unsuccessful attempts to resolve a matter of fraudulent accounts and inquiries appearing on my credit reports with all three major credit bureaus ( XXXX, TransUnion, and XXXX ). Despite my repeated efforts, these bureaus continue to violate my rights under multiple federal laws, and I demand immediate action to rectify this situation. 

Violations of Federal Law : Section 609 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) [ 15 U.S.C. 1681g ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) ] : The credit bureaus are legally required to provide accurate and verifiable information about each item on my credit report. The fraudulent accounts and inquiries listed below are clearly not mine, and the credit bureaus have failed to provide any documentation proving their legitimacy. 

12 CFR 1006.34 ( b ) ( 5 ) : This regulation mandates that debt collectors must clearly identify the name of the creditor and any information necessary to verify the validity of a debt. The credit bureaus have not complied with this requirement, continuing to report erroneous information without proper verification. 

FCRA Section 605B [ 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 ] : This section allows me to block fraudulent information resulting from identity theft, yet the bureaus have ignored my requests and continue to report the following fraudulent accounts and inquiries : Fraudulent Accounts : XXXX  XXXX, Open Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX, Open Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Date : XX/XX/XXXX Fraudulent Inquiries : XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX  XXXX, Inquiry Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Inquiry Date : XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Inquiry Date : XX/XX/XXXX FCRA Section 1681e ( b ) [ 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ] : The credit bureaus are required to maintain reasonable procedures to ensure maximum accuracy of the information they report. Their continued reporting of fraudulent accounts and inquiries, despite my disputes, demonstrates a clear violation of this obligation. 

15 U.S.C. 1692c : This statute prohibits debt collectors from contacting me regarding debts that I have clearly disputed as fraudulent. The credit bureaus persistence in reporting these items amounts to unlawful collection activity. 

15 U.S.C. 1681b : This section outlines permissible purposes for obtaining consumer reports. The inquiries listed above were not authorized by me and constitute unauthorized access to my credit information. 

My Demands : This is my third formal request for the immediate removal of the fraudulent accounts and inquiries from my credit reports. By continuing to report this inaccurate information, the credit bureaus are willfully violating federal law and causing significant harm to my financial standing. 

For each fraudulent item that remains on my credit report after this communication, I will pursue legal action and demand {$1000.00} in statutory damages per item, as well as additional compensation for the pain and suffering caused by the ongoing damage to my credit. Furthermore, I will seek punitive damages for the credit bureaus ' blatant disregard for federal law and my rights as a consumer.

And according to 15 USC 1681 5 they are suppose to do this ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In generallf, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( XXXX ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute the information reported by your company to the credit reporting agencies regarding an alleged late payment on my account, referenced under Account Number [ Your Account Number ]. Specifically, I dispute the claim that a payment was made late on [ Date of Alleged Late Payment ]. 

In XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, the court held that creditors must maintain accurate records and provide sufficient evidence when reporting information to credit agencies, particularly in cases of disputed information. In light of this precedent, I request that you provide me with the following : Copies of all internal records and documents that demonstrate the payment in question was, in fact, received late.

Detailed payment history of my account, including the dates and times when payments were posted to my account.

Evidence of notification sent to me regarding the alleged late payment.

Please provide this information within the timeframe prescribed by law. If your investigation concludes that the payment was not late or if you are unable to provide sufficient evidence, I request that you immediately correct the inaccurate information on my credit report and notify all credit reporting agencies to which you have reported this information.

Failure to comply with this request may result in further action, as inaccurate reporting can have significant consequences on my creditworthiness and overall financial standing.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your response and resolution of this dispute. 

Sincerely, [ XXXX XXXX ]

sed on, 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 5 ) this account is in violation not reporting 100 % accurate.. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute the unauthorized access and use of my bankruptcy information that was obtained without a permissible purpose under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically under 15 USC 1681a ( 2 ). 

I recently discovered that my bankruptcy information was accessed and reported by [ Name of the Entity or Source ], which, to my knowledge, does not have a permissible purpose for accessing this sensitive information. This action is in violation of the FCRA. 

Under 15 USC 1681b, a person or entity must have a permissible purpose to obtain my credit report or related information. As this entity does not meet the requirements for a permissible purpose, I request that you take the following actions : Investigate the unauthorized access and use of my bankruptcy information. 
Remove the bankruptcy information reported by the unauthorized entity from my credit report. 
Provide me with written confirmation of the actions taken and a copy of my updated credit report once the investigation is complete.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently reviewed my credit profile and discovered several credit card accounts and inquiries that can not be verified. Additionally, some information is not 100 % accurate, including incorrect names, outdated addresses, old phone numbers, and charge-off accounts. These inaccuracies violate the laws designed to protect consumers, which mandate that all reported information must be completely accurate. 

According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 USC 1681e ( b ) and 15 USC 1681i ( 5 ), all information on my credit report must be 100 % accurate. The presence of these fraudulent collections and incorrect details in my credit report constitutes a significant violation of this requirement.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions.

15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Against Experian for Violation of Fair Credit Reporting Act Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to file a formal complaint against Experian for its failure to properly investigate and remove inaccurate account information from my credit report in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 611 ). 
Account Information : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Amount : {$9900.00} I previously submitted a dispute to Experian regarding the inaccuracies in the above-referenced account. Despite providing evidence supporting the inaccuracies and requesting its removal from my credit report, Experian failed to conduct a thorough investigation and the disputed account remains on my credit report. 
As a consumer protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, I have the right to request the removal of inaccurate or outdated information from my credit report. Experian failure to comply with this law is a violation of my consumer rights and has caused me financial harm and distress. 
I respectfully request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter and take appropriate action against Experian for its non-compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act. I am seeking the immediate removal of the inaccurate account information from my credit report and appropriate measures to ensure that Experian upholds its obligations under the law. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a prompt resolution and your assistance in rectifying this issue. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Public record information inaccurate
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/2024 the credit company 's claimed that the information for a bankruptcy was verified. In your response you said the account was verified by XXXX XXXX, I disputed the accuracy of this information and they could not verify the account! You have violated my consumer rights. 
You stated that the account was verified, how did you come to possess this information? 
I am very sure I did not give you any permission ; no permissible purpose. 

15 USC 1681b ( A ) IN GENERAL Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : ( 2 ) In accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates.

When did I give you permission? Your action amounts to fraud and aggravated Identity theft 15 USC 1681q You Obtained my information under false pretenses. 

Any person who knowingly and willfully obtains information on a consumer from a consumer reporting agency under false pretenses shall be fined under title XXXX, imprisoned for not more than 2 years, or both. 

18 USC 1028A Whoever, during and in relation to any felony violation enumerated in subsection ( c ), knowingly transfers, possesses, or uses, without lawful authority, a means of identification of another person shall, in addition to the punishment provided for such felony, be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of 2 years.

You are guilty of obtaining my private non public personal information, you had no form of permissible purpose, you knowingly accessed my consumer report without any permissible purpose.

The account # that you have verified can not be verified, the data furnisher must verify this disputed request, yes both of you alleged that this account was verified, But as you can see, in the attachments the source you have used to tell you verified just deleted this inaccurate account in less from the consumer report.

Promptly delete this account from my credit reports and to every person you have furnished this inaccurate into to.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX  XXXX XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Experian XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX To Whom It May Concern, This letter is a formal complaint that you are reporting inaccurate and incomplete credit information. 
15 USC 1681e ( b ) Compliance and procedures ( b ) ACCURACY OF REPORT Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. 
Otherwise, anyone paying for your reporting services could fax, mail or email in a fraudulent account. 
I demand to see verifiable proof ( an original consumer contract with my signature on it ) that you have on file for the account listed below. Or a Certification from the creditor that certified the accuracy and completeness of the information/account. 
Your failure to positively verify these accounts has hurt my ability to obtain credit. Under the FCRA, unverifiable accounts must be DELETED and if you are unable to provide me a copy of verifiable proof, you must DELETE the account listed below. 
I demand that the following account be validated or DELETED immediately : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX In addition, DELETE all non-account holding inquiries over 30 days old. Also, please add a promotional suppression to my credit file. 
Under federal law, you have thirty ( 30 ) days to complete your re-investigation. Be advised that the description of the procedure used to determine the accuracy and completeness of the information is hereby requested as well, to be provided within fifteen ( 15 ) days of the completion of your re-investigation. 

Thank you, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX Equifax Information Services LLC XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX  XXXX To Whom It May Concern, This letter is a formal complaint that you are reporting inaccurate and incomplete credit information. 
15 USC 1681e ( b ) Compliance and procedures ( b ) ACCURACY OF REPORT Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. 
Otherwise, anyone paying for your reporting services could fax, mail or email in a fraudulent account. 
I demand to see verifiable proof ( an original consumer contract with my signature on it ) that you have on file for the account listed below. Or a Certification from the creditor that certified the accuracy and completeness of the information/account. 
Your failure to positively verify these accounts has hurt my ability to obtain credit. Under the FCRA, unverifiable accounts must be DELETED and if you are unable to provide me a copy of verifiable proof, you must DELETE the account listed below. 
I demand that the following account be validated or DELETED immediately : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX In addition, DELETE all non-account holding inquiries over 30 days old. Also, please add a promotional suppression to my credit file. 
Under federal law, you have thirty ( 30 ) days to complete your re-investigation. Be advised that the description of the procedure used to determine the accuracy and completeness of the information is hereby requested as well, to be provided within fifteen ( 15 ) days of the completion of your re-investigation. 

Thank you, XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Investigation took more than 30 days
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to dispute the accuracy of an item that has recently reappeared on my credit report. Specifically, the negative item reported by XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX has reappeared without any notification, contrary to the protections afforded to me under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1681 ). 
Relevant Information : This negative item was previously removed from my credit report. 
I was not notified of its reappearance, which is a violation of the FCRA 's requirements for consumer notification. 
\ Details of the Disputed Item : Account Name XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Notification to the Consumer : If the item is reinserted, the credit reporting agency is required to notify you within five business days. The notice must include the following : That the item has been reinserted. 
The name, address, and telephone number of the creditor or furnisher of the information. 
Your right to request a free copy of your credit report and to add a statement disputing the accuracy or completeness of the information.

15 USC 1666B ( a ) Time to make payments A creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date.

( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates.

15 USC 1637 Before opening any account under an open end consumer credit plan, the creditor shall disclose to the person to whom credit is to be extended each of the following items, to the extent applicable : ( 1 ) The conditions under which a finance charge may be imposed, including the time period ( if any ) within which any credit extended may be repaid without incurring a finance charge, except that the creditor may, at his election and without disclosure, impose no such finance charge if payment is received after the termination of such time period. If no such time period is provided, the creditor shall disclose such fact.

( 2 ) The method of determining the balance upon which a finance charge will be imposed.

( 3 ) The method of determining the amount of the finance charge, including any minimum or fixed amount imposed as a finance charge.

( 4 ) Where one or more periodic rates may be used to compute the finance charge, each such rate, the range of balances to which it is applicable, and the corresponding nominal annual percentage rate determined by multiplying the periodic rate by the number of periods in a year.

( 5 ) Identification of other charges which may be imposed as part of the plan, and their method of computation, in accordance with regulations of the Bureau.

( 6 ) In cases where the credit is or will be secured, a statement that a security interest has been or will be taken in ( A ) the property purchased as part of the credit transaction, or ( B ) property not purchased as part of the credit transaction identified by item or type.

( 7 ) A statement, in a form prescribed by regulations of the Bureau of the protection provided by sections 1666 and 1666i of this title to an obligor and the creditors responsibilities under sections 1666a and 1666i of this title. With respect to one billing cycle per calendar year, at intervals of not less than six months or more than eighteen months, the creditor shall transmit such statement to each obligor to whom the creditor is required to transmit a statement pursuant to subsection ( b ) for such billing cycle.

( 8 ) In the case of any account under an open end consumer credit plan which provides for any extension of credit which is secured by the consumers principal dwelling, any information which ( A ) is required to be disclosed under section 1637a ( a ) of this title; and ( B ) the Bureau determines is not described in any other paragraph of this subsection.

( b ) Statement required with each billing cycle The creditor of any account under an open end consumer credit plan shall transmit to the obligor, for each billing cycle at the end of which there is an outstanding balance in that account or with respect to which a finance charge is imposed, a statement setting forth each of the following items to the extent applicable : ( 1 ) The outstanding balance in the account at the beginning of the statement period.

( 2 ) The amount and date of each extension of credit during the period, and a brief identification, on or accompanying the statement of each extension of credit in a form prescribed by the Bureau sufficient to enable the obligor either to identify the transaction or to relate it to copies of sales vouchers or similar instruments previously furnished, except that a creditors failure to disclose such information in accordance with this paragraph shall not be deemed a failure to comply with this part or this subchapter if ( A ) the creditor maintains procedures reasonably adapted to procure and provide such information, and ( B ) the creditor responds to and treats any inquiry for clarification or documentation as a billing error and an erroneously billed amount under section 1666 of this title. In lieu of complying with the requirements of the previous sentence, in the case of any transaction in which the creditor and seller are the same person, as defined by the Bureau, and such persons open end credit plan has fewer than XXXX accounts, the creditor may elect to provide only the amount and date of each extension of credit during the period and the sellers name and location where the transaction took place if ( A ) a brief identification of the transaction has been previously furnished, and ( B ) the creditor responds to and treats any inquiry for clarification or documentation as a billing error and an erroneously billed amount under section 1666 of this title.

( b ) Opt out ( 1 ) In general A financial institution may not disclose nonpublic personal information to a nonaffiliated third party unless ( A ) such financial institution clearly and conspicuously discloses to the consumer, in writing or in electronic form or other form permitted by the regulations prescribed under section 6804 of this title, that such information may be disclosed to such third party ; ( B ) the consumer is given the opportunity, before the time that such information is initially disclosed, to direct that such information not be disclosed to such third party ; and ( C ) the consumer is given an explanation of how the consumer can exercise that nondisclosure option.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
It is very concerning what XXXX XXXX  does. I call every day to make sure this doesnt happen and they tell me to send an email and take days and days to respond. 

I was on Covid forbearance with XXXX lending and during this whole time XXXX protect me with the cares act of reporting XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX as delinquent on their mortgage. 

XXXX transfer me to XXXX in XXXX before doing the loss mitigation after coming out of XXXX forbearance. The cares act protect us from lender reporting us delinquent and XXXX knew this look at the letter attached. 

XXXX said they will do the deferment but didnt mentioned that we will have XXXX on escrow shortage that it was going to ballooned the payments. My first payment was due on XXXX - The supervisor told me to send a hardship application and we sent as the attachment shows. She also said during this process ( loss mitigation ) there is no negative reporting on credit bureau because its all originated from my XXXX forbearance. I asked her for a letter and she said all their calls are recorded. 

I sent my hardship application on XX/XX/XXXX. Before my first payment ( they said they take 30 days ) and still nothing but went ahead to report me today as default. 

They told me to send a letter to customer service to make sure they dont report me as the supervisor recommended because it protects me cares act and I did as the attachment shows and still no response.

I requested a dispute the debt listed on my credit report under the account XXXX XXXX as provided by XXXX. The request served as a formal request for debt validation under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), 15 USC 1692c.

I requested the following documentation and information : Full Payment History : I request a detailed record of the payment history associated with this account, including all payments made, amounts, and dates.

Original Contract Agreement : Please provide a copy of the original contract agreement bearing my signature that demonstrates my agreement to this debt with the creditor.

Insurance Claim : Indicate whether there is any insurance claim associated with this debt. If there is, please provide the details and documentation supporting the claim.

Chain of Title : Provide documentation that establishes the chain of title for this debt, demonstrating that the agencys had legal right to collect on this debt.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
Re : Formal Complaint Against TransUnion for Violation of FCRA Section 623 Due to Reinsertion of Previously Deleted Account XXXX XXXX Dear CFPB Representative, I am writing to file a formal complaint against TransUnion for violating my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically Section 623, by reinserting an account that was previously deleted from my credit report due to inaccuracy and discrepancy, THIS IS A VIOLATIONG TO THE LAWS Violation of 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) ( B ), Violation of 607 ( b ) AND Violation of 611 ( d ).

Account Number : [ XXXX XXXX ] Report Date : [ XX/XX/2024 ] I am writing to file a formal complaint against TransUnion LLC regarding the reinsertion of an account that was previously removed from my credit report due to inaccuracy in THE DATE ( XX/XX/2024 ) AFTER THEY HAD RECEIVED ( ATTACH : THIS IS THE LETTER SENT TO THE XXXX DISPUTING THE INACCURACIES ) XX/XX/2024 REGARDING THE VIOLATION AND INACCURACIES THAT THE ACCOUNT HAD ON XX/XX/2024, TRANSUNION SENT ME THE NOTIFICATION OF THE DELETION OF THE ACCOUNT ( XXXX  XXXX ) TO WHICH I AM ADDING PROOF THAT IT WAS SUCCESSFULLY REMOVED, BASED ON THE INACCURACIES AND DISCREPANCY THAT IT HAD BEFORE THE 30 DAYS OF THE INVESTIGATION HAD COMPLETED. 

Background On [ Date XX/XX/2024 ], I disputed an account listed on my credit report with TransUnion because the information was inaccurate. After a thorough investigation, TransUnion removed the account from my credit report in the ( date XX/XX/2024 ), acknowledging the inaccuracy. 

However, on [ XX/XX/2024 ], ( attach proof the reinsertion account ) I discovered that TransUnion had reinserted the previously deleted account into my credit report without proper notification or verification of the accuracy of the information. This action directly violates my rights under the FCRA.

This reinsertion has been done in clear violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). The specific sections of the FCRA that have been violated are as follows : Violation of Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) ( B ) - Reinsertion of Disputed Information : According to this section of the FCRA, if an item is deleted due to inaccuracy, it can not be reinserted into the credit report unless the information provider certifies that the information is complete and accurate. TransUnion did not provide me with any such certification or notification within the five business days required by law. Furthermore, the consumer must be notified in writing within five business days if the information is reinserted. 

In this case, the account identified as [ XXXX XXXX ] was previously removed from my credit report after I disputed its accuracy. However, TransUnion has reinserted this account without providing me with any verification of its accuracy or completeness, nor did I receive any notification from TransUnion within the required five-day period. 

2.Violation of Section 623 ( a ) ( 3 ) - Duty to Correct and Update Information : Under this section, the furnisher of the information has a duty to correct and update the information that is found to be inaccurate. The reinsertion of the previously removed account, without correcting the inaccuracy that led to its removal, constitutes a clear violation of this duty.

3.Violation of Section 611 ( d ) - Notification of Reinsertion : This section mandates that when a previously deleted item is reinserted, the credit bureau must notify the consumer in writing and provide a summary of their rights under the FCRA. TransUnion failed to provide any such notification, leaving me unaware of the reinsertion until I checked my report. REMOVE INMEDIATLY THE ACCOUNT FOR VIOLATION TO MY RIGHT.

TransUnion has failed to provide me with the required written notice and summary of my rights after reinserting the account. This failure constitutes a direct violation of my rights under the FCRA.

4. Violation of 607 ( b ) Section 607 ( b ) of the FCRA requires credit bureaus to maintain reasonable procedures to ensure the maximum possible accuracy of the information in consumer reports. By reinserting an account that was previously removed due to inaccuracy, TransUnion has demonstrated a failure to adhere to these procedures, resulting in a report that does not reflect accurate or reliable information.

Harm Caused The unauthorized reinsertion of this inaccurate account has caused significant harm, including potential damage to my credit score, increased stress, and the need to spend additional time and resources to correct the error. This has affected my ability to obtain credit on favorable terms and caused undue distress. Am very sad because is in the process to buy my home for my childs. please help that imposible than ONLY TRANSUNION REINSERT THIS ACCOUNT XXXX AND XXXX WAS DELETE DEFINITELY FOR INNACURATE THE PROOF IS ATTACH IN THIS COMPLAINT. AND THE PICTURES IS VERY CLEAR.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX RE : You Violated the United States Code Law NOTICE OF PENDING LITIGATION SEEKING RELIEF AND MONETARY COMPENSATION UNDER FCRA 15 U.S. Code 1681n Civil liability for willful noncompliance and 15 U.S. Code 1681o Civil liability for negligent noncompliance and 15 U.S. Code 1692k civil liability. 
Please accept this final written OFFER OF SETTLEMENT BEFORE LITIGATION as my attempt to amicably resolve your continued violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act regarding your refusal to delete INACCURATE, Unverifiable and Invalidated information from my consumer file. I intend to pursue litigation in accordance with the FCRA to seek relief and recover all monetary damages that I may be entitled to under Section 616 and Section 617 if the INACCURATE, Unverifiable and Invalidated items listed below are not deleted immediately. A copy of this letter as well as INACCURATE ERRONEOUS ITEMS sent to you previously will also become part of a formal complaint to the Federal Trade Commission and shall be used as evidence in pending litigation provided you fail to comply with this offer of settlement. 
YOU ARE IN DIRECT VIOLATION OF THE FCRA, the unverified items listed below still remain on my credit report in violation of Federal Law. You are required under the FCRA to have a copy of the original creditors documentation on file to verify that this information is mine and is correct. In the results of your investigations, you stated in writing that you verified that these items are being reported correctly Who verified these accounts? You have NOT provided me a copy of ANY original documentation ( a consumer contract with my signature on it ) as required under Section 609 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) & Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ). Furthermore, you have failed to provide the method of verification as required under Section 611 ( a ) ( 7 ). Please be advised that under Section 611 ( 5 ) ( A ) of the FCRA you are required to ... promptly DELETE all information which can not be verified.

Its very obvious that your agency doesnt know what the FCRA is because from the looks of my credit report and all the errors i see you are disregarding it so heres my breakdown.

1.The Fair Credit Reporting Act is the primary federal law that governs the collection and reporting of credit information about consumers. Its rules cover how a consumer 's credit information is obtained, how long it is kept, and how it is shared with othersincluding consumers themselves. 
2. What is a FCRA violation?

1 of 4 Creditors give reporting agencies inaccurate financial information about you.

Reporting agencies mixing up one person 's information with another 's because of similar ( or same ) last name or social security number. Agencies fail to follow guidelines for handling disputes.

3. My rights under the fair credit reporting act Verify the accuracy of my report when it is required for employment purposes. 
Receive notification if information in my file has been used against me in applying for credit or other transactions. 
Disputeand have the bureaus correct and deleteinformation in my report that is incomplete, inaccurate, and unverifiable.

Remove outdated, negative information ( after seven years in most cases, 10 in the case of bankruptcy ).

I demand these items be deleted immediately. I entered the items and the outcome I desire below because you are in violation and these items are not 100 % accurate and they are either INACCURATE, Unverifiable and Invalidated. I recently applied for extended credit and was denied i am in distress because of your mistakes. 
The law is very clear as to the Civil liability and the remedy available to me ( Section 616 & 617 ) if you fail to comply with Federal Law. I am a litigious consumer and fully intend on pursuing litigation in this matter to enforce my rights under the FCRA.

VIOLATION OF 15 U.S. Code 1681n - Civil liability for willful noncompliance ( a ) In general Any person who willfully fails to comply with any requirement imposed under this subchapter with respect to any consumer is liable to that consumer in an amount equal to the sum of ( 1 ) ( A ) any actual damages sustained by the consumer as a result of the failure or damages of not less than {$100.00} and not more than {$1000.00} ; or ( B ) in the case of liability of a natural person for obtaining a consumer report under false pretenses or knowingly without a permissible purpose, actual damages sustained by the consumeras a result of the failure or {$1000.00}, whichever is greater ; ( 2 ) such amount of punitive damages as the court may allow ; and ( 3 ) in the case of 3 of 4 any successful action to enforce any liability under this section, the costs of the action together with reasonable attorneys fees as determined by the court. 1.The Fair Credit Reporting Act is the primary federal law that governs the collection and reporting of credit information about consumers. Its rules cover how a consumer 's credit information is obtained, how long it is kept, and how it is shared with othersincluding consumers themselves.

2. What is a FCRA violation?

1 of 4 Creditors give reporting agencies inaccurate financial information about you.

Reporting agencies mixing up one person 's information with another 's because of similar ( or same ) last name or social security number. Agencies fail to follow guidelines for handling disputes.

3. My rights under the fair credit reporting act Verify the accuracy of my report when it is required for employment purposes. 
Receive notification if information in my file has been used against me in applying for credit or other transactions.

Disputeand have the bureaus correct and deleteinformation in my report that is incomplete, inaccurate, and unverifiable.

Remove outdated, negative information ( after seven years in most cases, 10 in the case of bankruptcy ).

The ( 16 ) accounts listed below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality contrary to : Title 15 of the United States Code section 1681 ; 15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A ; 15 U.S.C 1681 section604 A Section 2 ; 15 U.S.C. 1681c ( A ) ( 5 ) ; and, 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Complaint Right to Privacy According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act 15 USC 1681 section 602 A states " There is a need to ensure that consumer reporting agencies exercise their grave responsibilities with fairness, impartiality, and a respect for the consumers right to privacy. '' XXXX, Experian Information Solutions Inc. and XXXX are consumer reporting agencies and I am a Consumer with the right to make sure my private information isn't shared, see : 15 USC 6801 which provides : It is the policy of the Congress that each financial institution has an affirmative and continuing obligation to respect the privacy of its customers and to protect the security and confidentiality of those customers nonpublic personal information. ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) is a financial institution by definition under that title.

15 USC 1681 section 604 a section 2, which states : " In general Subject to subsection ( c ), any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : in accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. '' ( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) the financial institution and the Consumer reporting agencies XXXX, Experian Information Solutions Inc. and XXXX are wanting consent to furnish information. Any and all, perceived or otherwise, consent to XXXX, Experian Information Solutions Inc. and XXXX, whether it be verbal, non-verbal, written, implied or otherwise are hereby revoked.

( Furnisher of information to credit agencies ) Never informed me of my right to exercise my nondisclosure option.

15 USC 1681C ( a ) ( 5 ) states Except as authorized under subsection ( b ), no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information : Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years. These accounts are inaccurate, are adverse items reporting without permission, of which are against the law.

XXXX, Experian Information Solutions Inc. and XXXX are not maintaining reasonable procedures. Also 12 CFR 1016.7 states that A consumer may exercise the right to opt out at any time. I, XXXX XXXX XXXX, hereby opting out of the reporting services.

I kindly request that you block this information from my credit report within >>>>>>4 BUSINESS DAYS<<<<<<<<<pursuant to 605C of the Fair Reporting Credit Act. I am a victim of XXXX XXXX of debt bondange and would like for all listed accounts to be blocked and removed from Equifax. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX {$1300.00} According to the FCRA, specifically : 1. **Section 605B** : Requires the deletion of information resulting from identity theft. 2. **Section 611** : Provides the right to dispute information in my credit file. 3. **Section 623** : Requires that furnishers of information to credit reporting agencies ensure the accuracy and integrity of the information provided. 4. 15 USC 1681 Section 602 states I have a right to privacy. 5. **15 USC 1681 Section 604 ( a ) Section 2 states a credit reporting agency can not furnish an account without my written instructions. 6. 15 USC 1666 ( b ) a creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to Despite my previous attempts to resolve this issue with both the creditor and your agency, the inaccuracies remain on my report. In addition, please note that if this matter is not resolved promptly, I will be compelled to escalate my complaint to the Attorney General 's office. This step is necessary due to the multiple failed attempts to address this matter through the proper channels. I will be waiting for 30 days before I escalate this matter any further ( FRCA section 611 ( A ) ( 1 ) .According to FRCA Section 604 ( A ) ( 3 ), please provide proof of signature giving the the approval to pull my credit report, run my credit report, or do any kind of business. If you can not verify the debt, please remove this off my account for the THIRD TIME!!! According to FRCA section 605 ( c ) you are in error by even updating this account! I am disputing all inaccuracies including my address.

Consumer complaint narrative:
NOTICE TO AGENT IS NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL NOTICE TO PRINCAL IS NOTICE TO AGENT You XXXX XXXX are furnishing inaccurate and incorrect information to the consumer reporting agencies. 

The reporting of such inaccurate information has caused severe damage to my character, my reputation, my general mode of living and my ability to obtain credit for personal and house purposes. 

You and your inaccurate reporting have damaged my livelihood. 

15 U.S. Code 16815-2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( A ) Reporting information with actual knowledge of errors A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 

Duty : a moral or legal obligation ; a responsibility Accurate : correct in all details ; exact. 

PROHIBITION : a law or regulation forbidding something As Defined by The IRS Even if you didn't receive a Form 1099-C, you must report canceled debt as gross income on your tax return.

The IRS Clearly defines a charge off as Gross or Ordinary income, INCOME DOES NOT GET REPORTED ON THE CONSUMER REPORT which in fact makes your reporting of this account inaccurate. 

By Definition The IRS Clearly says a Cancelled or Charge off is Income. The reporting of this account as a debt is in accurate. 

15 USC 1681 s-2 Says you XXXX XXXX are a furnisher of information to a consumer reporting agency. 

You ARE PROHIBITED BY LAW to furnish inaccurate information. I demand you to cease and Desist the reporting of incorrect in accurate information immediately. 

15 USC 1681 5-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate You are hereby put on NOTICE that you are furnishing incorrect inaccurate information. 
The lender must file Form 1099-C and send you a copy if the amount of debt canceled is {$600.00} or more and the lender is a financial institution, credit union , federal government agency, or other applicable entity as discussed earlier in XXXX XXXX 

The above paragraph is taken directly from the IRS 2024 publication. 

SEND ME MY FORM 1099-C that you should have sent when you filled the account as a canceled debt. 

15 U.S. Code 16815-2 ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if- A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if- ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate ; and ( il ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate. 

In conclusion I have shown you and you have been put on notice that you are reporting inaccurate information. 

The information is, in fact, inaccurate. 

The continued reporting of this inaccurate information is a clear violation of the Law 15 USC 1681 s-2 of your responsibilities as a furnisher of information. 

You have caused me and my family severe harm due to your negligence and inaccurate reporting. This is a final opportunity to Cure and DELETE This Erroneous, inaccurate account from my Consumer report. 

YOU HAVE XXXX Calendar days to DELETE THIS ACCOUNT FROM MY CONSUMER REPORTS! 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX GA XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Notice to agent is notice to principal notice to principal is notice to agent You [ XXXX, Transunion, XXXX replied that the alleged transaction you furnished as late was { accurate/ verified } but my previous dispute did not ask you for accuracy or validation. 
On { XX/XX/XXXX } you { XXXX, Transunion, XXXX } reported an alleged transaction as Late.

15 U.S. Code 1666b - Timing of payments ( a ) Time to make payments A creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date. 
15 USC 1681e ( b ) ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates.

I requested the information that you must have or possess by law in order for you to report a payment as late.

This is being request pursuant rule 1002.

In other words, to properly report information as verified, the furnisher must have sufficient evidence to support the conclusion that the information was true, and in doing this the conditions required by 15 USC 1666b must be met.

You failed to provide the required requested information, you failed to proceed in accordance with the requires for a creditor to treat a payment as late and the evidence that must be sent to you to prove that this transaction was late. 
It has been over 30 days and you have not properly verify the information. 
Id. at XXXX ; see also XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ) ( defining verify as [ t ] o prove to be true ; to confirm or establish the truth or truthfulness of ; to authenticate ). 
15 U.S. Code 1681i - Procedure in case of disputed accuracy ( a ) Reinvestigations of disputed information ( 1 ) Reinvestigation required ( A ) In general Subject to subsection ( f ) and except as provided in subsection ( g ), if the completeness or accuracy of any item of information contained in a consumers file at a consumer reporting agency is disputed by the consumer and the consumer notifies the agency directly, or indirectly through a reseller, of such dispute, the agency shall, free of charge, conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate and record the current status of the disputed information, or delete the item from the file in accordance with paragraph ( 5 ), before the end of the 30-day period beginning on the date on which the agency receives the notice of the dispute from the consumer or reseller.

Importantly, a furnishers inability to conclusively determine that the disputed information is inaccurate does not mean that the furnisher is permitted to report back to the consumer reporting agency that its investigation verified the accuracy of that information. Instead, if the evidence available to the furnisher is insufficient to establish the truth or falsity of the disputed information, then, under the statutory framework, the furnisher must report that its investigation concluded that the disputed information can not be verified. 
XXXX, XXXX XXXX at XXXX. So, for example, if a furnisher is unable to verify that a consumer missed a payment, then it may be appropriate for the furnisher to delete any mentions of the missed payment while continuing to report other information about the account.

I am requesting pursuant 15 USC 1681i ( 6 ) Notice of results of reinvestigation ( B ) Contents ( iii ) a notice that, if requested by the consumer, a description of the procedure used to determine the accuracy and completeness of the information shall be provided to the consumer by the agency, including the business name and address of any furnisher of information contacted in connection with such information and the telephone number of such furnisher.

when disputed information can not be verified is to delete that information. In particular, Section 1681i outlines consumer reporting agencies responsibilities in responding to consumers disputes and, like Section 1681s-2 ( b ), provides that when a disputed item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency must delete or modify it as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ( A ). Section 1681i goes on to provide that, [ f ] ollowing any deletion of information which is found to be inaccurate or whose accuracy can no longer be verified, the consumer reporting agency must in some circumstances notify certain people who previously received a report with the now-deleted information. That provision thus contemplates that when information can no longer be verified, the proper response is to delet [ e ] it. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Information belongs to someone else
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you as a last resort after multiple unsuccessful attempts to resolve a matter of fraudulent accounts and inquiries appearing on my credit reports with all three major credit bureaus ( XXXX, XXXX, and Equifax ). Despite my repeated efforts, these bureaus continue to violate my rights under multiple federal laws, and I demand immediate action to rectify this situation. 

Violations of Federal Law : Section 609 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) [ 15 U.S.C. 1681g ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) ] : The credit bureaus are legally required to provide accurate and verifiable information about each item on my credit report. The fraudulent accounts and inquiries listed below are clearly not mine, and the credit bureaus have failed to provide any documentation proving their legitimacy. 

12 CFR 1006.34 ( b ) ( 5 ) : This regulation mandates that debt collectors must clearly identify the name of the creditor and any information necessary to verify the validity of a debt. The credit bureaus have not complied with this requirement, continuing to report erroneous information without proper verification. 

FCRA Section 605B [ 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 ] : This section allows me to block fraudulent information resulting from identity theft, yet the bureaus have ignored my requests and continue to report the following fraudulent accounts and inquiries : Fraudulent Accounts : XXXX  XXXX, Open Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX, Open Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Date : XX/XX/XXXX Fraudulent Inquiries : XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX  XXXX, Inquiry Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX  Inquiry Date : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Inquiry Date : XX/XX/XXXX FCRA Section 1681e ( b ) [ 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) ] : The credit bureaus are required to maintain reasonable procedures to ensure maximum accuracy of the information they report. Their continued reporting of fraudulent accounts and inquiries, despite my disputes, demonstrates a clear violation of this obligation. 

15 U.S.C. 1692c : This statute prohibits debt collectors from contacting me regarding debts that I have clearly disputed as fraudulent. The credit bureaus persistence in reporting these items amounts to unlawful collection activity. 

15 U.S.C. 1681b : This section outlines permissible purposes for obtaining consumer reports. The inquiries listed above were not authorized by me and constitute unauthorized access to my credit information. 

My Demands : This is my third formal request for the immediate removal of the fraudulent accounts and inquiries from my credit reports. By continuing to report this inaccurate information, the credit bureaus are willfully violating federal law and causing significant harm to my financial standing. 

For each fraudulent item that remains on my credit report after this communication, I will pursue legal action and demand {$1000.00} in statutory damages per item, as well as additional compensation for the pain and suffering caused by the ongoing damage to my credit. Furthermore, I will seek punitive damages for the credit bureaus ' blatant disregard for federal law and my rights as a consumer.

Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than XXXX years. 

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Sub-issue: Information belongs to someone else
Consumer complaint narrative: This letter is to provide you with knowledge of intent to sue. The lawsuit will filed due to the utter lack of response from your company. When someone is the victim of identity theft, it is simply a nightmare trying to get false information removed from a credit file. I have contacted all of the false creditors listed on my credit file. I have challenged all of the false listings on my credit file. Nothing ever happens to fix the situation. Over 90 days ago I wrote each the creditors in question and demanded proof that I am their customer. I asked for proof of the alleged debt, including specifically the alleged contract or other instrument bearing my signature. So far none of them has been able to provide such proof to me. I have sent follow-up letters to each of them and there is still no proof. I have attempted phone contact, but I simply get transferred around and nothing ever gets accomplished. I have fully investigated my rights in this matter. Under the doctrine of estoppel by silence, XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, I may presume that no proof of the alleged debt, nor therefore any such debt, in fact exists. I have copies of the certified letters and dates prepared to bring to court. Also, under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, these disputed items may not appear on my credit report if they can not be supported by any evidence. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, if they can not verify the debt within 30 days, then it must be removed. Your letters to me claim to have " verified '' the debt, but this is in fact not true under law. Simply contacting the alleged creditor and asking them to match up numbers in their database is no sufficient verification for identity theft. Of course the information matches up. Someone clearly used my information without my authorization. Now I am suing Experian for being such a pain in the posterior to me. I have provided more than sufficient evidence to get these false accounts removed. Feel free to reach out to address this issue before it escalates legally.. via letter at my address listed at the top of this letter. This matter can be settled simply by your agreement to remove the false information from my credit file. I require a response, on point, in writing, hand signed, and in a timely manner. If I get another pointless letter from you saying that it has already been " verified '' then there will be no more opportunity for negotiation. This will proceed in court until I have successfully proven to a judge that this false information must be removed from my credit file. I will also be aggressively pursuing the full judgment that I can get against Experian for violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act and Defamation. Accounts that I didn't authorize and had no knowledge of or reporting accurately, police report and FTC report is on file, Please DELETE THEM Account Name XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Against Transunion for Violation of Fair Credit Reporting Act Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to file a formal complaint against Transunion for its failure to properly investigate and remove inaccurate account information from my credit report in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 611 ).

Account Information : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Amount : {$9900.00} I previously submitted a dispute to Transunion regarding the inaccuracies in the above-referenced account. Despite providing evidence supporting the inaccuracies and requesting its removal from my credit report, Transunion failed to conduct a thorough investigation and the disputed account remains on my credit report.

As a consumer protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, I have the right to request the removal of inaccurate or outdated information from my credit report. Transunion failure to comply with this law is a violation of my consumer rights and has caused me financial harm and distress.

I respectfully request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter and take appropriate action against Transunion for its non-compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act. I am seeking the immediate removal of the inaccurate account information from my credit report and appropriate measures to ensure that Transunion upholds its obligations under the law.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a prompt resolution and your assistance in rectifying this issue.

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative: Dear I am writing to dispute inaccurate information regarding a charge-off account listed on my credit report. I have found multiple inconsistencies in the information reported by the three credit bureaus, and I request an investigation and correction of these discrepancies. *Disputed Account Information : * - Creditor : XXXX - Account Number : [ XXXX ) Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the right to dispute inaccurate information on my credit report. I request that you investigate these discrepancies and correct any inaccuracies. Please contact the original creditor to verify the correct information. Right to Accurate Information ( FCRA Section 609 ) : Under Section 609 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681g ), I have the right to obtain and dispute the completeness and accuracy of the information in my credit report. I request that you investigate and verify the accuracy of the reported charge-off. If the information can not be verified, it must be removed. Reinvestigation of Disputed Information ( FCRA Section 1681i ) : Under Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), I have the right to request a reinvestigation of any information I believe to be incorrect or inaccurate on my credit report. I demand that you review and correct this information immediately.Removal of Inaccurate/Invalidated Credit Information ( 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 5 ) ) : As per Section 611 ( 5 ) of the FCRA, if, after a reinvestigation of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of information is found to be inaccurate or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall promptly delete such information from the consumers file. Responsibilities of Information Providers ( FCRA Section 1681s-2 ) : Under Section 623 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ), information providers must ensure the accuracy and completeness of the information reported. The inclusion of this incorrect charge-off information represents a clear violation of this section.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Difficulty submitting a dispute or getting information about a dispute over the phone
Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/year>, I ordered a table from XXXX XXXX that was advertised as ready to ship. After three weeks with no shipment, I contacted XXXX XXXX, and they informed me that it would be several months before the table would be available. I decided to cancel my order and notified XXXX, through XXXX XXXX, about the cancellation. XXXX instructed me to wait for XXXX XXXX to process the refund. 

At the end of XXXX, I received an email from XXXX XXXX confirming the cancellation and stating that I would be refunded within XXXX business days. However, the refund did not arrive. I then opened a dispute on the XXXX XXXX app, but continued to receive non-payment notifications. When I called XXXX, they suggested opening a dispute but consistently failed to follow through. Despite my efforts to resolve the issue, including forwarding over 15 emails from XXXX XXXX, XXXX claimed they did not receive these emails and suggested I reach out to XXXX XXXX directly. 

Throughout this process, I was advised to continue making payments to avoid affecting my credit score. However, despite my clear communication that I wanted to resolve the issue and avoid credit damage, XXXX did not formally open a dispute. Consequently, they reported the issue to the credit bureaus, which severely impacted my credit score. 

This unresolved situation has placed an undue financial burden on me, hindering my ability to secure a mortgage at a reasonable rate. After exhausting all efforts to resolve the matter, I eventually paid the total amount. I have since filed a complaint with the Ohio Attorney Generals office, yet I have still not received a refund from either XXXX XXXX or XXXX, and the issue remains on my credit report.
