Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Against Equifax for Violation of Fair Credit Reporting Act Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to file a formal complaint against Equifax for its failure to properly investigate and remove inaccurate account information from my credit report in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 611 ).

Account Information : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX  Account Number : XXXX Amount : {$8400.00} I previously submitted a dispute to Equifax regarding the inaccuracies in the above-referenced account. Despite providing evidence supporting the inaccuracies and requesting its removal from my credit report, [ Equifax ] failed to conduct a thorough investigation and the disputed account remains on my credit report.

As a consumer protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, I have the right to request the removal of inaccurate or outdated information from my credit report. Equifax failure to comply with this law is a violation of my consumer rights and has caused me financial harm and distress.

I respectfully request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter and take appropriate action against Equifax for its non-compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act. I am seeking the immediate removal of the inaccurate account information from my credit report and appropriate measures to ensure that Equifax upholds its obligations under the law.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a prompt resolution and your assistance in rectifying this issue.

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Against Experian for Violation of Fair Credit Reporting Act Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to file a formal complaint against Experian for its failure to properly investigate and remove inaccurate account information from my credit report in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 611 ). 
Account Information : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX  Account Number : XXXX Amount : {$9900.00} I previously submitted a dispute to Experian regarding the inaccuracies in the above-referenced account. Despite providing evidence supporting the inaccuracies and requesting its removal from my credit report, Experian failed to conduct a thorough investigation and the disputed account remains on my credit report. 
As a consumer protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, I have the right to request the removal of inaccurate or outdated information from my credit report. Experian failure to comply with this law is a violation of my consumer rights and has caused me financial harm and distress. 
I respectfully request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter and take appropriate action against Experian for its non-compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act. I am seeking the immediate removal of the inaccurate account information from my credit report and appropriate measures to ensure that Experian upholds its obligations under the law. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a prompt resolution and your assistance in rectifying this issue. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
NOTICE TO AGENT IS NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL NOTICE TO PRINCAL IS NOTICE TO AGENT You XXXX XXXX XXXX are furnishing inaccurate and incorrect information to the consumer reporting agencies. 

The reporting of such inaccurate information has caused severe damage to my character, my reputation, my general mode of living and my ability to obtain credit for personal and house purposes. 

You and your inaccurate reporting have damaged my livelihood. 

15 U.S. Code 16815-2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION XXXX ) PROHIBITION ( A ) Reporting information with actual knowledge of errors A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 

Duty : a moral or legal obligation ; a responsibility Accurate : correct in all details ; exact. 

PROHIBITION : a law or regulation forbidding something As Defined by The IRS Even if you didn't receive a Form 1099-C, you must report canceled debt as gross income on your tax return. 

The IRS Clearly defines a charge off as Gross or Ordinary income, INCOME DOES NOT GET REPORTED ON THE CONSUMER REPORT which in fact makes your reporting of this account inaccurate. 

By Definition The IRS Clearly says a Cancelled or Charge off is Income. The reporting of this account as a debt is in accurate. 

15 USC 1681 s-2 Says you XXXX XXXX XXXX are a furnisher of information to a consumer reporting agency. 

You ARE PROHIBITED BY LAW to furnish inaccurate information. I demand you to cease and Desist the reporting of incorrect in accurate information immediately. 

15 USC 1681 5-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate You are hereby put on NOTICE that you are furnishing incorrect inaccurate information. 
The lender must file Form 1099-C and send you a copy if the amount of debt canceled is {$600.00} or more and the lender is a financial institution, credit union , federal government agency, or other applicable entity as discussed earlier in chapter XXXX. 

The above paragraph is taken directly from the IRS XXXX  publication. 

SEND ME MY FORM 1099-C that you should have sent when you filled the account as a canceled debt. 

15 U.S. Code 16815-2 ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if- A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if- ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate ; and ( il ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate. 

In conclusion I have shown you and you have been put on notice that you are reporting inaccurate information. 

The information is, in fact, inaccurate. 

The continued reporting of this inaccurate information is a clear violation of the Law 15 USC 1681 s-2 of your responsibilities as a furnisher of information.

You have caused me and my family severe harm due to your negligence and inaccurate reporting. This is a final opportunity to Cure and DELETE This Erroneous, inaccurate account from my Consumer report. 

YOU HAVE 10 Calendar days to DELETE THIS ACCOUNT FROM MY CONSUMER REPORTS! 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am a victim of identity theft, and despite my repeated efforts to notify XXXX, Equifax, and XXXX about the fraudulent information on my credit reports, they have failed to remove the inaccurate addresses, phone numbers, and employers that do not belong to me. This situation has caused me significant distress and has the potential to harm my financial well-being. 

I have sent multiple letters to Equifax, XXXX, and XXXX detailing the fraudulent information and requesting its removal, but to no avail. The addresses, phone numbers, and employers listed on my credit reports are not associated with me, and their presence is a result of identity theft. 

The fraudulent accounts and personal information on my credit reports, as well as the addresses mentioned in the documents I provided, clearly indicate that my identity has been compromised. Despite my efforts to rectify this situation, the credit bureaus have failed to take appropriate action. 

I urge the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to investigate this matter thoroughly and ensure that XXXX, Equifax, and XXXX comply with the Fair Credit Reporting Act. It is crucial that the inaccurate and fraudulent information on my credit reports is promptly removed to prevent further harm to my financial reputation and well-being. 

Your prompt attention to this matter is greatly appreciated.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear I am writing to dispute inaccurate information regarding a charge-off account listed on my credit report. I have found multiple inconsistencies in the information reported by the XXXX credit bureaus, and I request an investigation and correction of these discrepancies. 
*Disputed Account Information : * - Creditor : XXXX  - Account Number : [ XXXX ) Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), I have the right to dispute inaccurate information on my credit report. I request that you investigate these discrepancies and correct any inaccuracies. Please contact the original creditor to verify the correct information. Right to Accurate Information ( FCRA Section 609 ) : Under Section 609 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681g ), I have the right to obtain and dispute the completeness and accuracy of the information in my credit report. I request that you investigate and verify the accuracy of the reported charge-off. If the information can not be verified, it must be removed. Reinvestigation of Disputed Information ( FCRA Section 1681i ) : Under Section 611 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ), I have the right to request a reinvestigation of any information I believe to be incorrect or inaccurate on my credit report. I demand that you review and correct this information immediately.Removal of Inaccurate/Invalidated Credit Information ( 15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 5 ) ) : As per Section 611 ( 5 ) of the FCRA, if, after a reinvestigation of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of information is found to be inaccurate or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall promptly delete such information from the consumers file. 
Responsibilities of Information Providers ( FCRA Section 1681s-2 ) : Under Section 623 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ), information providers must ensure the accuracy and completeness of the information reported. The inclusion of this incorrect charge-off information represents a clear violation of this section.

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you for this time regarding the accounts listed below that continue to appear on my credit report. Despite my repeated attempts to have these inaccuracies corrected, these accounts remain on my report, negatively impacting my credit score and causing me undue stress and hardship. I am once again formally requesting that these accounts be permanently removed from my credit report. This request is made under the provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which obligates credit reporting agencies to ensure the accuracy of the information they report. These are the following accounts : XXXX. XXXX XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - It seems that the following information reported is incorrect : account number, payment status, and date open. Get it right immediately ; otherwise, update the account from my report. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - You are reporting different information from other bureaus. Per FCRA, reporting must be 100 % accurate or the information must be updated. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - Please check the Payment History and Status information on this account and adjust accordingly. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - Please check the status of this account. It is entirely wrong, to begin with. I was never late on this account. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - My record shows that this account was paid as Agreed and I never missed a payment. Please update it immediately. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - The number of late payments is incorrect. I never missed a payment. Please adjust immediately. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - I requested an investigation and the removal of the charge-off status. No changes were made. No investigation was conducted at all. You had optimal time to review this matter and make the appropriate corrections, you elected not to. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXXalance Owed : {$200.00} - The limit to this account was a fraction of the amount due as stated. That is utterly unfathomable! Had a proper investigation been conducted you would have seen the error and corrected it immediately. You failed to do your job ; you must now REMOVE THIS ITEM ALTOGETHER.

Did I give you written instructions to furnish this on my credit report?

Delete the above late payments from my consumer report, this agency is in violation of 15 USC 1681.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Personal information incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Against Equifax for Improper Handling of Credit Information Dear CFPB Members, I am writing to formally file a complaint against Equifax for the re-insertion of outdated and incorrect personal information in my credit report, despite my prior request for its removal. This situation violates my rights under both federal and state consumer protection laws. 

According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq., I have the right to dispute inaccurate information on my credit report. Under this law, Equifax is required to investigate disputes within 30 days and correct or delete any inaccurate or unverifiable information. The re-insertion of incorrect information without proper notification is a direct violation of the FCRA, specifically section 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ( B ). 

*MY NAME IS : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX CA XXXX XXXX XXXX Employment History In the state of California, the California Consumer Credit Reporting Agencies Act ( CCCRAA ), Cal. Civ. Code 1785.1 et seq., also protects my rights. This law requires credit reporting agencies to maintain reasonable procedures to ensure the accuracy and confidentiality of information and prohibits the re-insertion of outdated information. Specifically, section 1785.16 requires credit agencies to investigate and correct errors within 30 days of receiving a dispute. 

Therefore, I request that Equifax : Immediately remove the incorrect and outdated information from my credit report. 
Provide an updated copy of my credit report with the corrections made. 
Ensure that such information is not re-inserted without proper verification. 
If Equifax fails to comply with these requests, I will proceed to take the following actions : File a formal complaint with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ). 
I appreciate your prompt attention to this matter and look forward to a resolution as outlined above. I am attaching copies of my identification, the relevant credit report, and any supporting documentation for your reference.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My account with XXXX XXXX was never late! I have had exceptional payment history witH XXXX XXXXXXXX and all payments were placed on Autopay. This late payment that is reporting is a result on a systematic error on their end processing my payment. 

This was clearly a billing error made my the company and is not a reflection of my payment experience which violates USC Code 1681eb. This error has caused severe hard to my reputation, my character, my mode of living and to my family!

I demand the late payment reported to be removed.

They are not in compliance with the following law. 15 USC 1666b and its requirements set the standards and the guidance for a creditor to treat a payment as late, yet they are reporting a payment as late and they did not comply with the law!

15 USC 1666b ( a ) Time to make payments A creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date. 

XXXX XXXX never sent the periodic statement along with the disclosures from section 1637 ( b ).

I have requested proof that this information was mailed or delivered 21 days before the payment due date and this information was requested in good faith pursuant rule 1002 and It was never provided.

This is unfair, illegal, fraudulent, and not equitable to me as a consumer!

Delete the late payments from my consumer reports

Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX.

Consumer complaint narrative:
My account with XXXX XXXX was never late! I have had exceptional payment history witH XXXX XXXXXXXX and all payments were placed on Autopay. This late payment that is reporting is a result on a systematic error on their end processing my payment.

T

his was clearly a billing error made my the company and is not a reflection of my payment experience which violates USC Code 1681eb. This error has caused severe hard to my reputation, my character, my mode of living and to my family! I demand the late payment reported to be removed. They are not in compliance with the following law. 15 USC 1666b and its requirements set the standards and the guidance for a creditor to treat a payment as late, yet they are reporting a payment as late and they did not comply with the law! 

15 USC 1666b ( a ) Time to make payments A creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date. 

XXXX XXXX never sent the periodic statement along with the disclosures from section XXXX ( b ). 

I have requested proof that this information was mailed or delivered 21 days before the payment due date and this information was requested in good faith pursuant rule XXXX and It was never provided. 

This is unfair, illegal, fraudulent, and not equitable to me as a consumer! 

Delete the late payments from my consumer reports

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Information belongs to someone else
Consumer complaint narrative:
The Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S. Code 1681 ) says ( 1 ) The banking system is dependent upon fair and accurate credit reporting. Inaccurate credit reports directly impair the efficiency of the banking system, and unfair credit reporting methods undermine the public confidence which is essential to the continued functioning of the banking system.

So whenever there is a violation under the FCRA, it impairs the efficiency of the banking system. This is a violation of my privacy with my consumer report, since I control what is listed and what is not. In the event that any accounts are reported without my written consent, that is considered identity theft.

This is a violation of both 15 U.S. Code 1681b ( 2 ) and 15 U.S. Code 1681c-2. This leads way to civil liability against the credit reporting agency for negligent and willful noncompliance under 15 U.S. Code 1681n, which allows for {$1000.00} per violation, for account listed without my expressed written consent.

2. However, this information has not been provided, despite multiple requests.

3. Timeline of Investigation : There is a lack of clarity on the timeline of the investigation, including key dates and actions taken during the process. This lack of transparency hinders my ability to understand how the investigation was conducted and whether it adhered to FCRA requirements.

Please find the ATTACHED documents to assist in the blocking of the erroneous information which is being posted to my report.

Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Against Equifax for Violation of Fair Credit Reporting Act Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to file a formal complaint against Equifax for its failure to properly investigate and remove inaccurate account information from my credit report in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 USC 611 ). 
Account Information : Creditor Name : XXXXXXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Amount : {$18000.00} I previously submitted a dispute to [ Equifax ] regarding the inaccuracies in the above-referenced account. Despite providing evidence supporting the inaccuracies and requesting its removal from my credit report, Equifax failed to conduct a thorough investigation and the disputed account remains on my credit report. 
As a consumer protected under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, I have the right to request the removal of inaccurate or outdated information from my credit report. Equifax failure to comply with this law is a violation of my consumer rights and has caused me financial harm and distress. 
I respectfully request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter and take appropriate action against Equifax for its non-compliance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act. I am seeking the immediate removal of the inaccurate account information from my credit report and appropriate measures to ensure that Equifax upholds its obligations under the law. 
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to a prompt resolution and your assistance in rectifying this issue. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
NOTICE TO AGENT IS NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL NOTICE TO PRINCAL IS NOTICE TO AGENT You XXXX XXXX XXXX are furnishing inaccurate and incorrect information to the consumer reporting agencies. 

The reporting of such inaccurate information has caused severe damage to my character, my reputation, my general mode of living and my ability to obtain credit for personal and house purposes. 

You and your inaccurate reporting have damaged my livelihood. 

15 U.S. Code 16815-2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( A ) Reporting information with actual knowledge of errors A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 

Duty : a moral or legal obligation ; a responsibility Accurate : correct in all details ; exact. 

PROHIBITION : a law or regulation forbidding something As Defined by The IRS Even if you didn't receive a Form 1099-C, you must report canceled debt as gross income on your tax return. 

The IRS Clearly defines a charge off as Gross or Ordinary income, INCOME DOES NOT GET REPORTED ON THE CONSUMER REPORT which in fact makes your reporting of this account inaccurate. 

By Definition The IRS Clearly says a Cancelled or Charge off is Income. The reporting of this account as a debt is in accurate. 

15 USC 1681 s-2 Says you XXXX XXXX XXXX are a furnisher of information to a consumer reporting agency. 

You ARE PROHIBITED BY LAW to furnish inaccurate information. I demand you to cease and Desist the reporting of incorrect in accurate information immediately. 

15 USC 1681 5-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate You are hereby put on NOTICE that you are furnishing incorrect inaccurate information. 
The lender must file Form 1099-C and send you a copy if the amount of debt canceled is {$600.00} or more and the lender is a financial institution, credit union , federal government agency, or other applicable entity as discussed earlier in chapter XXXX. 

The above paragraph is taken directly from the IRS XXXX  publication. 

SEND ME MY FORM 1099-C that you should have sent when you filled the account as a canceled debt. 

15 U.S. Code 16815-2 ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if- A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if- ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate ; and ( il ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate. 

In conclusion I have shown you and you have been put on notice that you are reporting inaccurate information. 

The information is, in fact, inaccurate. 

The continued reporting of this inaccurate information is a clear violation of the Law 15 USC 1681 s-2 of your responsibilities as a furnisher of information. 

You have caused me and my family severe harm due to your negligence and inaccurate reporting. This is a final opportunity to Cure and DELETE This Erroneous, inaccurate account from my Consumer report. 

YOU HAVE 10 Calendar days to DELETE THIS ACCOUNT FROM MY CONSUMER REPORTS! 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
The Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S. Code 1681 ) says ( 1 ) The banking system is dependent upon fair and accurate credit reporting. Inaccurate credit reports directly impair the efficiency of the banking system, and unfair credit reporting methods undermine the public confidence which is essential to the continued functioning of the banking system.

So whenever there is a violation under the FCRA, it impairs the efficiency of the banking system. This is a violation of my privacy with my consumer report, since I control what is listed and what is not. In the event that any accounts are reported without my written consent, that is considered identity theft.

This is a violation of both 15 U.S. Code 1681b ( 2 ) and 15 U.S. Code 1681c-2. This leads way to civil liability against the cred
it reporting agency for negligent and willful noncompliance under 15 U.S. Code 1681n, which allows for {$1000.00} per violation, for account listed without my expressed written consent.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to you for this time regarding the accounts listed below that continue to appear on my credit report. Despite my repeated attempts to have these inaccuracies corrected, these accounts remain on my report, negatively impacting my credit score and causing me undue stress and hardship. I am once again formally requesting that these accounts be permanently removed from my credit report. This request is made under the provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which obligates credit reporting agencies to ensure the accuracy of the information they report. These are the following accounts : XXXX. XXXX XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - It seems that the following information reported is incorrect : account number, payment status, and date open. Get it right immediately ; otherwise, update the account from my report. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - You are reporting different information from other bureaus. Per FCRA, reporting must be 100 % accurate or the information must be updated. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - Please check the Payment History and Status information on this account and adjust accordingly. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - Please check the status of this account. It is entirely wrong, to begin with. I was never late on this account. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - My record shows that this account was paid as Agreed and I never missed a payment. Please update it immediately. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - The number of late payments is incorrect. I never missed a payment. Please adjust immediately. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX Balance Owed : {$0.00} - XXXX requested an investigation and the removal of the charge-off status. No changes were made. No investigation was conducted at all. You had optimal time to review this matter and make the appropriate corrections, you elected not to. 

XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXXalance Owed : {$200.00} - The limit to this account was a fraction of the amount due as stated. That is utterly unfathomable! Had a proper investigation been conducted you would have seen the error and corrected it immediately. You failed to do your job ; you must now REMOVE THIS ITEM ALTOGETHER.

Despite my previous efforts to resolve this matter, these items remain on my report, causing significant harm to my credit and financial well-being. Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX  XXXX Pa, XXXX XX/XX/XXXX Trans Union LLC XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX, PA XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, TX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, GA XXXX To Whom It May Concern : I recently received a copy of my ( XXXX, XXXX, or TransUnion ) credit report, and I noticed some late payments posted on my credit report : XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Your company is in clear violation of the law. Under 15 USC 1681b - permissible purpose of consumer reports, THE LAW CLEARLY STATES : ( a ) IN GENERAL Subject to subsection ( c ) any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report under the following circumstances and no other : Co ( 2 ) In accordance with the written instructions of the consumer to whom it relates. 
Did I give you written instructions to furnish this on my credit report? 
Furthermore, the FAIR CREDIT REPORTING ACT 15 USC 1681 ( 2 ) ( a ) ( i ) Exclusions from a consumer credit report clearly states : ( 2 ) EXCLUSIONS. -Except as provided in paragraph ( 3 ), the term " consumer report '' does not include- ( A ) Subject to section 1681s-3 of this title, any ( i ) report containing information solely as to transactions or experiences between the consumer and the person making the report.

Delete the above late payments from my consumer report, this agency is in violation of 15 USC 1681.

Failure to respond satisfactorily with deletion of the above referenced account, and send out a free copy of my report after the changes have been made will result in legal actions being taken against your company, for which | will also be seeking {$1000.00} per violation for : 1. Defamation of Character ( per se ) Negligent Enablement of Identity Fraud Fair Debt Collections Practices Act 15 USC 1692g violations Fair Credit Reporting Act 15USC 1681 violations for willful noncompliance - 616. Civil liability for willful noncompliance [ 15 U.S.C. 1681n ] Best regards, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently reviewed my credit profile and discovered several credit card accounts and inquiries that can not be verified. Additionally, some information is not 100 % accurate, including incorrect names, outdated addresses, old phone numbers, and charge-off accounts. These inaccuracies violate the laws designed to protect consumers, which mandate that all reported information must be completely accurate. 

According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically 15 USC 1681e ( b ) and 15 USC 1681i ( 5 ), all information on my credit report must be 100 % accurate. The presence of these fraudulent collections and incorrect details in my credit report constitutes a significant violation of this requirement.

Consumer complaint narrative:
CAPITAL ONE BANK USA Revolving with account # XXXX opened on XX/XX/year> and a balance of {$4700.00}. 
This account is incorrectly being reported as a charged off account with a balance due. Please provide proof of the charge off and update the balance to {$0.00} or delete the negative payment status on this account. 
CAPITAL ONE BANK USA Revolving with account # XXXX opened on XX/XX/year> and a balance of {$840.00}. 
This account is incorrectly reporting negative payment history on my credit report. Because I am only an authorized user on this account, I am not responsible for the balance incurred by the primary cardholder nor am I responsible for any missed payments on this account. 
XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Revolving with account # XXXX opened on XX/XX/year> and a balance of {$1400.00}. 
This account is incorrectly being reported as a charged off account with a balance due. Please provide proof of the charge off and update the balance to {$0.00} or delete the negative payment status on this account. 
XXXX XXXX Installment with account # XXXX opened on XX/XX/year> and a balance of {$21000.00}. 
This account is incorrectly being reported as a charged off account with a balance due. Please provide proof of the charge off and update the balance to {$0.00} or delete the negative payment status on this account. 
Collection account from XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX with account # XXXX and a balance of {$6500.00}. The original creditor is XXXX XXXX GA. 

I never had a contract with this debt collector for any debt. Please provide proof from the original creditor that this debt collector owns this debt and has the legal authority to collect it or delete this account. 
Please reinvestigate these matters and delete or correct the disputed information as soon as possible. 

UCC : * XXXX. EFFECT OF ERRORS OR OMISSIONS. 
* XXXX. NOTIFICATION BEFORE DISPOSITION OF COLLATERAL * XXXX. TIMELINESS OF NOTIFICATION BEFORE DISPOSITION OF COLLATERAL. 
* XXXX. CONTENTS AND FORM OF NOTIFICATION BEFORE DISPOSITION OF COLLATERAL You are required to provide me with copies of the legal notices and proof of the commercially reasonable manner of the notification and resale of the subject vehicle. If no such proof is provided within 15 days from receipt of this certified mail notice, the alleged claim of a deficiency will be considered null and void, and any continued collection activities, or continued reporting of this invalid claim on my credit reports will be considered a violation of the FDCPA and FCRA. In addition, if you singularly or severally fail to comply with the above requests, I reserve the right to seek damages against all parties, under all available State and Federal statutes and including but not limited to UCC 9-625 remedies. Furthermore, you are hereby notified that at no point in time and under no circumstances is your company ; an employee of your company ; a representative for your company or affiliates are to contact me or any family members by any means other than the US mail system.

I am writing to formally dispute the unauthorized access and use of my bankruptcy information that was obtained without a permissible purpose under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), specifically under 15 USC 1681a ( 2 ).

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
15 U.S. Code 1692c - Communication in connection with debt collection ( a ) CoMMUnication WitH tHe conSUMeR GeneRallY Without the prior consent of the consumer given directly to the debt collector or the express permission of a court of competent jurisdiction, a debt collector may not communicate with a consumer in connection with the collection of any debt ( c ) CeaSinG coMMUnication If a consumer notifies a debt collector in writing that the consumer refuses to pay a debt or that the consumer wishes the debt collector to cease further communication with the consumer, the debt collector shall not communicate further with the consumer with respect to such debt, except ( 1 ) to advise the consumer that the debt collectors further efforts are being terminated ; ( 2 ) to notify the consumer that the debt collector or creditor may invoke specified remedies which are ordinarily invoked by such debt collector or creditor ; or ( 3 ) where applicable, to notify the consumer that the debt collector or creditor intends to invoke a specified remedy.

If such notice from the consumer is made by mail, notification shall be complete upon receipt.

A debt collector may not engage in any conduct the natural consequence of which is to harass, oppress, or abuse any person in connection with the collection of a debt. Without limiting the general application of the foregoing, the following conduct is a violation of this section : ( 1 ) The use or threat of use of violence or other criminal means to harm the physical person, reputation, or property of any person.

( 2 ) The use of obscene or profane language or language the natural consequence of which is to abuse the hearer or reader.

( 3 ) The publication of a list of consumers who allegedly refuse to pay debts, except to a consumer reporting agency or to persons meeting the requirements of section 1681a ( f ) or 1681b ( 3 ) [ 1 ] of this title.

( 4 ) The advertisement for sale of any debt to coerce payment of the debt.

( 5 ) Causing a telephone to ring or engaging any person in telephone conversation repeatedly or continuously with intent to annoy, abuse, or harass any person at the called number.

( 6 ) Except as provided in section 1692b of this title, the placement of telephone calls without meaningful disclosure of the callers identity. 
( Pub. L. 90321, title VIII, 806, as added Pub. L. 95109, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX. ) I have not supplied proof under the doctrine of estoppel by silence, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( mo ) XXXX XXXX XXXX, I presume that no proof of the alleged debt, nor therefore any such debt, in fact therefor exists pursuant to 18 USC 8, L owe no debt, this company is violation my consumer right to privacy pursuant to 15 USC 1681-B2 company has no permission to report my information per 15 USC 16814 .
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Account status incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
Notice to Agent is Notice to Principal, Notice to Principal is Notice to Agent You replied that the alleged transaction you furnished as late was but my previous dispute did not ask you for accuracy or validation. 
You you furnished to { XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX } as an alleged trans

action as Late. 15 U.S. Code 1666b - Timing of payments ( a ) Time to make payments A creditor may not treat a
payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date. 
I requested the information that must have or possess by law in order for you to furnish a payment as late. 
This is being request pursuant rule 1002. 
In other words, to properly report information as verified, the furnisher must have sufficient evidence to support the conclusion that the information was true, and in doing this the conditions required by 15 USC 1666b must be met. 
You failed to provide the required requested information, you failed to proceed in accordance with the requires for a creditor to treat a payment as late. 
It has been over 30 days and you have not properly verify the information. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX ; see also XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX  ) ( defining verify as [ t ] o prove to be true ; to confirm or establish the truth or truthfulness of ; to authenticate ). 
Importantly, a furnishers inability to conclusively determine that the disputed information is inaccurate does not mean that the furnisher is permitted to report back to the consumer reporting agency that its investigation verified the accuracy of that information. Instead, if the evidence available to the furnisher is insufficient to establish the truth or falsity of the disputed information, then, under the statutory framework, the furnisher must report that its investigation concluded that the disputed information can not be verified. 
XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. So, for example, if a furnisher is unable to verify that a consumer missed a payment, then it may be appropriate for the furnisher to delete any mentions of the missed payment while continuing to report other information about the account. 
Delete the information you are furnishing to the Consumer Reporting Agencies as late from account. 

XXXX XXXX _________________________________ Without Recourse UCC 1-308

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Revolving with account # XXXX opened on XX/XX/year> and a balance of {$4700.00}. 
This account is incorrectly being reported as a charged off account with a balance due. Please provide proof of the charge off and update the balance to {$0.00} or delete the negative payment status on this account. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Revolving with account # XXXX opened on XX/XX/year> and a balance of {$840.00}. 
This account is incorrectly reporting negative payment history on my credit report. Because I am only an authorized user on this account, I am not responsible for the balance incurred by the primary cardholder nor am I responsible for any missed payments on this account. 
XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Revolving with account # XXXX opened on XX/XX/year> and a balance of {$1400.00}. 
This account is incorrectly being reported as a charged off account with a balance due. Please provide proof of the charge off and update the balance to {$0.00} or delete the negative payment status on this account. 
XXXX XXXX Installment with account # XXXX opened on XX/XX/year> and a balance of {$21000.00}. 
This account is incorrectly being reported as a charged off account with a balance due. Please provide proof of the charge off and update the balance to {$0.00} or delete the negative payment status on this account. 
Collection account from XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX with account # XXXX and a balance of {$6500.00}. The original creditor is XXXX XXXX GA. 

I never had a contract with this debt collector for any debt. Please provide proof from the original creditor that this debt collector owns this debt and has the legal authority to collect it or delete this account. 
Please reinvestigate these matters and delete or correct the disputed information as soon as possible. 

UCC : * XXXX. EFFECT OF ERRORS OR OMISSIONS. 
* XXXX. NOTIFICATION BEFORE DISPOSITION OF COLLATERAL * XXXX. TIMELINESS OF NOTIFICATION BEFORE DISPOSITION OF COLLATERAL. 
* XXXX. CONTENTS AND FORM OF NOTIFICATION BEFORE DISPOSITION OF COLLATERAL You are required to provide me with copies of the legal notices and proof of the commercially reasonable manner of the notification and resale of the subject vehicle. If no such proof is provided within 15 days from receipt of this certified mail notice, the alleged claim of a deficiency will be considered null and void, and any continued collection activities, or continued reporting of this invalid claim on my credit reports will be considered a violation of the FDCPA and FCRA. In addition, if you singularly or severally fail to comply with the above requests, I reserve the right to seek damages against all parties, under all available State and Federal statutes and including but not limited to UCC 9-625 remedies. Furthermore, you are hereby notified that at no point in time and under no circumstances is your company ; an employee of your company ; a representative for your company or affiliates are to contact me or any family members by any means other than the US mail system.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally dispute the information reported by your company to the credit reporting agencies regarding an alleged late payment on my account, referenced under Account Number [ Your Account Number ]. Specifically, I dispute the claim that a payment was made late on [ Date of Alleged Late Payment ]. 

In XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ), the court held that creditors must maintain accurate records and provide sufficient evidence when reporting information to credit agencies, particularly in cases of disputed information. In light of this precedent, I request that you provide me with the following : Copies of all internal records and documents that demonstrate the payment in question was, in fact, received late. 
Detailed payment history of my account, including the dates and times when payments were posted to my account. 
Evidence of notification sent to me regarding the alleged late payment. 
Please provide this information within the timeframe prescribed by law. If your investigation concludes that the payment was not late or if you are unable to provide sufficient evidence, I request that you immediately correct the inaccurate information on my credit report and notify all credit reporting agencies to which you have reported this information. 

Failure to comply with this request may result in further action, as inaccurate reporting can have significant consequences on my creditworthiness and overall financial standing. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your response and resolution of this dispute. 

Sincerely, [ XXXX XXXX ]

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Account status incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a complaint against XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX, Experian, and XXXX for inaccurate reporting of a charged-off debt, violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ), the Privacy Act of 1974, and the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ). 

XXXX XXXX XXXX has reported a charged-off debt to XXXX, Experian, and XXXX on my credit report. This is in violation of the FDCPA, which states that when an account is more than 180 days past due, it must generally be charged off. Despite being charged off, XXXX XXXX XXXX has failed to provide me with a 1099-C form, as required by IRS code 4681. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX has violated the FCRA ( 15 US. .Code 1681s2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies ) by reporting inaccurate information to the credit bureaus. Specifically, they have reported the charged-off debt without having reasonable cause to believe that the information is accurate. This has severely affected my overall score and financial stability. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX actions also violate the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ) - 12 CFR 31.3 and the CFPA 's prohibition against unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts or practices. By continuing to report the charged-off account as a debt, XXXX XXXX XXXX is engaging in deceptive conduct that harms consumers. 

Furthermore, XXXX XXXX XXXX has violated my rights under the Privacy Act of 1974. The Privacy Act of 1974, as amended, 5 U.S.C. 552a, establishes a code of fair information practices that governs the collection, maintenance, use, and dissemination of information about individuals that is maintained in systems of records by federal agencies. A system of records is a group of records under the control of an agency from which information is retrieved by the name of the individual or by some identifier assigned to the individual. The Privacy Act prohibits the disclosure of a record about an individual from a system of records absent the written consent of the individual, unless the disclosure is pursuant to one of twelve statutory exceptions. XXXX XXXX XXXX improperly disclosed my personal information to credit reporting agencies, specifically XXXX, Experian, and XXXX. 

Additionally, XXXX XXXX XXXX has violated the GLBA ( 15 U.S.C. 6802, also known as section 502 ( b ) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ) by failing to provide me with a clear and conspicuous notice of their intent to share my nonpublic personal information with nonaffiliated third parties, such as XXXX, Experian, and XXXX. This coincides with 16 CFR 313.7 ( Form of opt out notice to consumers ; opt out methods ) 16 CFR 313.10 ( Limits on disclosure of non-public personal information to nonaffiliated third parties ) and 248.124 ( Reasonable opportunity to opt out ). 

Supporting Documentation : Credit Reports Opt Out Letter to XXXX XXXX XXXX that was ignored FDCPA Documentation concerning charge-off statuses Requested Relief : I request that the CFPB investigate this matter and take appropriate action against XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, Experian, and XXXX. I seek the removal of the inaccurate information from my credit report, as well as compensation deemed appropriate and upholding the law per violation committed. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
15 U.S. Code 1692c - Communication in connection with debt collection ( a ) CoMMUnication WitH tHe conSUMeR GeneRallY Without the prior consent of the consumer given directly to the debt collector or the express permission of a court of competent jurisdiction, a debt collector may not communicate with a consumer in connection with the collection of any debt ( c ) CeaSinG coMMUnication If a consumer notifies a debt collector in writing that the consumer refuses to pay a debt or that the consumer wishes the debt collector to cease further communication with the consumer, the debt collector shall not communicate further with the consumer with respect to such debt, except ( 1 ) to advise the consumer that the debt collectors further efforts are being terminated ; ( 2 ) to notify the consumer that the debt collector or creditor may invoke specified remedies which are ordinarily invoked by such debt collector or creditor ; or ( 3 ) where applicable, to notify the consumer that the debt collector or creditor intends to invoke a specified remedy. 
If such notice from the consumer is made by mail, notification shall be complete upon receipt. 

A debt collector may not engage in any conduct the natural consequence of which is to harass, oppress, or abuse any person in connection with the collection of a debt. Without limiting the general application of the foregoing, the following conduct is a violation of this section : ( 1 ) The use or threat of use of violence or other criminal means to harm the physical person, reputation, or property of any person. 
( XXXX ) The use of obscene or profane language or language the natural consequence of which is to abuse the hearer or reader. 
( XXXX ) The publication of a list of consumers who allegedly refuse to pay debts, except to a consumer reporting agency or to persons meeting the requirements of section 1681a ( f ) or 1681b ( 3 ) [ 1 ] of this title. 
( XXXX ) The advertisement for sale of any debt to coerce payment of the debt. 
( XXXX ) Causing a telephone to ring or engaging any person in telephone conversation repeatedly or continuously with intent to annoy, abuse, or harass any person at the called number. 
( XXXX ) Except as provided in section 1692b of this title, the placement of telephone calls without meaningful disclosure of the callers identity. 
( Pub. XXXX XXXX, title XXXX, XXXX, as added Pub. XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX XXXX. XXXX. ) I have not supplied proof under the doctrine of estoppel by silence, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX  ) XXXX XXXX XXXX, I presume that no proof of the alleged debt, nor therefore any such debt, in fact therefor exists pursuant to 18 USC 8, L owe no debt, this company is violation my consumer right to privacy pursuant to 15 USC 1681-B2 company has no permission to report my information per 15 USC 16814 .
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Information belongs to someone else
Consumer complaint narrative:
The Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S. Code 1681 ) says ( 1 ) The banking system is dependent upon fair and accurate credit reporting. Inaccurate credit reports directly impair the efficiency of the banking system, and unfair credit reporting methods undermine the public confidence which is essential to the continued functioning of the banking system.

So whenever there is a violation under the FCRA, it impairs the efficiency of the banking system. This is a violation of my privacy with my consumer report, since I control what is listed and what is not. In the event that any accounts are reported without my written consent, that is considered identity theft.

This is a violation of both 15 U.S. Code 1681b ( 2 ) and 15 U.S. Code 1681c-2. This leads way to civil liability against the credit reporting agency for negligent and willful noncompliance under 15 U.S. Code 1681n, which allows for {$1000.00} per violation, for account listed without my expressed written consent.

15 U.S. Code 1692c - Communication in connection with debt collection ( a ) CoMMUnication WitH tHe conSUMeR GeneRallY Without the prior consent of the consumer given directly to the debt collector or the express permission of a court of competent jurisdiction, a debt collector may not communicate with a consumer in connection with the collection of any debt ( c ) XXXX XXXX If a consumer notifies a debt collector in writing that the consumer refuses to pay a debt or that the consumer wishes the debt collector to cease further communication with the consumer, the debt collector shall not communicate further with the consumer with respect to such debt, except ( 1 ) to advise the consumer that the debt collectors further efforts are being terminated ; ( 2 ) to notify the consumer that the debt collector or creditor may invoke specified remedies which are ordinarily invoked by such debt collector or creditor ; or ( 3 ) where applicable, to notify the consumer that the debt collector or creditor intends to invoke a specified remedy.

If such notice from the consumer is made by mail, notification shall be complete upon receipt.

A debt collector may not engage in any conduct the natural consequence of which is to harass, oppress, or abuse any person in connection with the collection of a debt. Without limiting the general application of the foregoing, the following conduct is a violation of this section : ( 1 ) The use or threat of use of violence or other criminal means to harm the physical person, reputation, or property of any person.

( 2 ) The use of obscene or profane language or language the natural consequence of which is to abuse the hearer or reader.

( 3 ) The publication of a list of consumers who allegedly refuse to pay debts, except to a consumer reporting agency or to persons meeting the requirements of section 1681a ( f ) or 1681b ( 3 ) [ 1 ] of this title.

( 4 ) The advertisement for sale of any debt to coerce payment of the debt.

( 5 ) Causing a telephone to ring or engaging any person in telephone conversation repeatedly or continuously with intent to annoy, abuse, or harass any person at the called number.

( 6 ) Except as provided in section 1692b of this title, the placement of telephone calls without meaningful disclosure of the callers identity.

According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, negative information like late payments must be removed from credit reports after seven years, unless it's an error. After seven years, the negative mark will no longer affect your credit score. You can check your credit report to make sure the mark has been removed, and if it hasn't, you can file a dispute with the relevant credit bureau. Disputes are free and won't hurt your credit score.

Consumer complaint narrative:
To whom it may concern : According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), you are required to promptly delete all information that is inaccurate, incomplete, or unverified. I am now enacting my consumer and civil rights to compel you to annul with permanent deletion these derogatory accounts or provide testimony and certification that you are adhering to mandated metro 2 data formatted reporting standards according to regulations. The following derogatory account allegations are either untrue, unverified, incorrect, incomplete, untimely, not mine, not my responsibility, or otherwise not proven in compliance with regulatory federal reporting laws and or standards and must be removed immediately. 
Below is a summary of the data in which I am challenging : Personal Information for Experian NAME : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Please make sure your company 's records are up-to date and accurate. I only have one name, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
If you have any other name listed for me, please delete it immediately. 
CURRENT ADDRESS : XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXXXXXX XX/XX/year> XXXX My only address is XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX Please make sure you remove any address in your system which does not match the address listed on this letter. 
Appreciatively As a consumer, I have listed the concerns about your reporting in this document. It is not complete and does not meet applicable standards because according to law you are required for both FCRAs as well as Metro 2 compliance which must be done truthfully with correct information being provided timely so that none of my rights are violated XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Please send your written response to my address of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
I am aware that you have been sending out form letters in response to many of the disputes and challenges that consumers have submitted, regardless of the specific information that they have provided. This is illegal, as each dispute and challenge must be addressed individually and on its own merits.My letters were created using software that is available to everyone. If you don't process my letters, you are violating 15 U.S. Code 5 1681i. Keep in mind, you are not allowed to delay processing letters from consumers based on the assumption that help from a third party may be available. This is not a legal exception.I am the author of any letters you receive with my name on them. Either I or my advisors wrote them with my full knowledge and consent. I am aware that there is no law that says you need to provide a Power of Attorney in order to delay processing letters from a consumer.If you do not process my letters in a timely manner, I will consider it to be an intentional disregard of my rights as a consumer. I will then contact my lawyer to take legal action

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Account status incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
Notice to agent is notice to principal notice to principal is notice to agent You [ XXXX, XXXX, Equifax replied that the alleged transaction you furnished as late was { accurate/ verified } but my previous dispute did not ask you for accuracy or validation. 
On { XX/XX/XXXX } you { XXXX, XXXX, Equifax } reported an alleged transaction as Late.

15 U.S. Code 1666b - Timing of payments ( a ) Time to make payments A creditor may not treat a payment on a credit card account under an open end consumer credit plan as late for any purpose, unless the creditor has adopted reasonable procedures designed to ensure that each periodic statement including the information required by section 1637 ( b ) of this title is mailed or delivered to the consumer not later than 21 days before the payment due date. 
15 USC 1681e ( b ) ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates.

I requested the information that you must have or possess by law in order for you to report a payment as late.

This is being request pursuant rule 1002.

In other words, to properly report information as verified, the furnisher must have sufficient evidence to support the conclusion that the information was true, and in doing this the conditions required by 15 USC 1666b must be met.

You failed to provide the required requested information, you failed to proceed in accordance with the requires for a creditor to treat a payment as late and the evidence that must be sent to you to prove that this transaction was late. 
It has been over 30 days and you have not properly verify the information. 
Id. at XXXX ; see also XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX. XXXX ) ( defining verify as [ t ] o prove to be true ; to confirm or establish the truth or truthfulness of ; to authenticate ). 
15 U.S. Code 1681i - Procedure in case of disputed accuracy ( a ) Reinvestigations of disputed information ( 1 ) Reinvestigation required ( A ) In general Subject to subsection ( f ) and except as provided in subsection ( g ), if the completeness or accuracy of any item of information contained in a consumers file at a consumer reporting agency is disputed by the consumer and the consumer notifies the agency directly, or indirectly through a reseller, of such dispute, the agency shall, free of charge, conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate and record the current status of the disputed information, or delete the item from the file in accordance with paragraph ( 5 ), before the end of the 30-day period beginning on the date on which the agency receives the notice of the dispute from the consumer or reseller. 

Importantly, a furnishers inability to conclusively determine that the disputed information is inaccurate does not mean that the furnisher is permitted to report back to the consumer reporting agency that its investigation verified the accuracy of that information. Instead, if the evidence available to the furnisher is insufficient to establish the truth or falsity of the disputed information, then, under the statutory framework, the furnisher must report that its investigation concluded that the disputed information can not be verified. 
XXXX, XXXX XXXX at XXXX. So, for example, if a furnisher is unable to verify that a consumer missed a payment, then it may be appropriate for the furnisher to delete any mentions of the missed payment while continuing to report other information about the account. 
I am requesting pursuant 15 USC 1681i ( 6 ) Notice of results of reinvestigation ( B ) Contents ( iii ) a notice that, if requested by the consumer, a description of the procedure used to determine the accuracy and completeness of the information shall be provided to the consumer by the agency, including the business name and address of any furnisher of information contacted in connection with such information and the telephone number of such furnisher.

when disputed information can not be verified is to delete that information. In particular, Section 1681i outlines consumer reporting agencies responsibilities in responding to consumers disputes and, like Section 1681s-2 ( b ), provides that when a disputed item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency must delete or modify it as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation. 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ( A ). Section 1681i goes on to provide that, [ f ] ollowing any deletion of information which is found to be inaccurate or whose accuracy can no longer be verified, the consumer reporting agency must in some circumstances notify certain people who previously received a report with the now-deleted information. That provision thus contemplates that when information can no longer be verified, the proper response is to delet [ e ] it. I am filing a complaint against XXXX XXXX XXXX, Transunion, XXXX, and XXXX for inaccurate reporting of a charged-off debt, violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ), the Privacy Act of 1974, and the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ). 

XXXX XXXX XXXX has reported a charged-off debt to Transunion, XXXX, and XXXX on my credit report. This is in violation of the FDCPA, which states that when an account is more than 180 days past due, it must generally be charged off. Despite being charged off, XXXX XXXX XXXX has failed to provide me with a 1099-C form, as required by IRS code 4681. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX has violated the FCRA ( 15 US. .Code 1681s2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies ) by reporting inaccurate information to the credit bureaus. Specifically, they have reported the charged-off debt without having reasonable cause to believe that the information is accurate. This has severely affected my overall score and financial stability. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX actions also violate the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ) - 12 CFR 31.3 and the CFPA 's prohibition against unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts or practices. By continuing to report the charged-off account as a debt, XXXX XXXX XXXX is engaging in deceptive conduct that harms consumers. 

Furthermore, XXXX XXXX XXXX has violated my rights under the Privacy Act of 1974. The Privacy Act of 1974, as amended, 5 U.S.C. 552a, establishes a code of fair information practices that governs the collection, maintenance, use, and dissemination of information about individuals that is maintained in systems of records by federal agencies. A system of records is a group of records under the control of an agency from which information is retrieved by the name of the individual or by some identifier assigned to the individual. The Privacy Act prohibits the disclosure of a record about an individual from a system of records absent the written consent of the individual, unless the disclosure is pursuant to one of twelve statutory exceptions. XXXX XXXX XXXX improperly disclosed my personal information to credit reporting agencies, specifically Transunion, XXXX, and XXXX. 

Additionally, XXXX XXXX XXXX has violated the GLBA ( 15 U.S.C. 6802, also known as section 502 ( b ) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ) by failing to provide me with a clear and conspicuous notice of their intent to share my nonpublic personal information with nonaffiliated third parties, such as Transunion, XXXX, and XXXX. This coincides with 16 CFR 313.7 ( Form of opt out notice to consumers ; opt out methods ) 16 CFR 313.10 ( Limits on disclosure of non-public personal information to nonaffiliated third parties ) and 248.124 ( Reasonable opportunity to opt out ). 

Supporting Documentation : Credit Reports Opt Out Letter to XXXX XXXX XXXX that was ignored FDCPA Documentation concerning charge-off statuses Requested Relief : I request that the CFPB investigate this matter and take appropriate action against XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Transunion, XXXX, and XXXX. I seek the removal of the inaccurate information from my credit report, as well as compensation deemed appropriate and upholding the law per violation committed. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern at Experian, XXXX and XXXX, I am writing to express my deep concern over Experian, XXXX, XXXX furthermore known as " the XXXX bureaus '' failure to investigate my mailed-in disputes, resulting in a violation of my rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). I have received a response letter from " the XXXX bureaus '' indicating that my mailed-in dispute request " does not appear to have been sent directly by [ me ] or to be authorized by [ me ], '' which is not only inaccurate but also constitutes a failure to investigate my disputes as required by the FCRA. 
Let me be clear : I have never used a credit repair company or any third party to submit disputes on my behalf. I am the sole author and sender of each dispute I submit to " the XXXX bureaus '', and I have provided notarized documentation along with identification to prove my identity. There should be no ambiguity regarding the legitimacy of my mailed-in disputes. 
According to FCRA 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), if a consumer disputes the accuracy or completeness of information in their credit report, the credit reporting agency must conduct a free reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate. " The XXXX bureaus '' refusal to investigate my mailed-in disputes on the grounds that they " do not appear to have been sent directly by [ me ] '' is a clear violation of this provision. 
" The XXXX bureaus '' ongoing practice of sending letters that delay the investigation process by questioning the authenticity of my disputes is unacceptable and constitutes a significant breach of my rights under the FCRA. By failing to conduct a timely and thorough investigation into my disputes, " the XXXX bureaus '' is causing unnecessary delays, which impacts my creditworthiness and financial well-being. 
I demand that " the XXXX bureaus '' promptly address this issue by : 1. Opening and investigating every mailed-in dispute that I submit upon receipt.

2. Stopping the practice of sending letters that question the legitimacy of my disputes without valid grounds.

3. Complying with FCRA regulations that mandate the investigation of disputes submitted by consumers. 
If " the XXXX bureaus '' fails to comply with these demands and continues to violate my rights under the FCRA, I will take further action, including but not limited to filing complaints with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) and pursuing legal remedies to enforce my rights. 
Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. I expect a response confirming that " the XXXX bureaus '' has corrected its practices and will properly investigate my mailed-in disputes in accordance with FCRA requirements. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Issue: Problem caused by your funds being low
Sub-issue: Overdrafts and overdraft fees
Consumer complaint narrative: On Tuesday XXXX XXXX between XXXX I received 3 consecutive email confirmation for 3 orders placed online through my personal rewards member XXXX XXXX account at a XXXX XXXX located in Washington DC. The email also contained the address where the food was to be delivered by XXXX and a contact phone number for the person who placed the order. Apparently the XXXX XXXX website saved my debit card on file from the last time I ordered food from there at my location here in XXXX. The person who ordered the food somehow hacked my XXXX XXXX account. I emailed XXXX XXXX customer service and they've agreed cooperate with any investigation. I was at work ( here in XXXX XXXX XXXX Tx ) at the time this happened. I submitted a claim to Regions Bank which they closed and denied the very next day without asking me anything. I never even got a confirmation email that was received which is standard practice. Regions still hit me with an overdraft fee for each of those fraudulent transactions even though a dispute had already been submitted for them. When I called the bank to complain about the charges, is when I learned they closed and denied my claim without any investigation which should also be a standard practice being that it is a dispute. The representative told the reason it was denied is because I did not dispute transactions I actually made at my XXXX XXXX a month or 2 ago. OBVIOUSLY ITS BECAUSE THOSE ARE LEGIT PURCHASES I MADE GENIUSES! And it was not even a question on their online dispute form! It never asked about other transactions with XXXX XXXX from last month. If that information was pertinent to the claim decision, then it should have been asked! In addition, the online dispute form does not have a way to upload information. I had the email confirmation for the orders that were being delivered to someone in Washington. I have my timecard which shows I was working at the time!! But you didn't ask for anything!! Then just closed my claim and charged me {$160.00} for the overdraft those transactions caused me!! Talk about predatory!! You should not be allowed to add overdraft fees on transactions that have been disputed!! And you seriously need to update your online dispute form! There's nowhere to upload documents and your free text box to enter additional details has a character cap so you can't even fully explain everything in that text box! Your bank needs to be fined for this! Now when my direct deposit goes in on Wednesday, I'll be short {$160.00} because of your predatory fees!!

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX  # XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX # XXXX, has violated my rights. 

I looked at my XXXX credit report on XX/XX/2024 and noticed some things are incomplete and not accurate. And according to the fair credit reporting act Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates according to 15 USC 1681 ( e ) ( b ).

And according to 15 USC 1681 5 they are suppose to do this ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In generallf, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shall ( i ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer. 

and according to 15 USC 1681s-2 they are suppose to not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.
