Consumer complaint narrative:
I opened a XXXX XXXX  credit card that had a {$95.00} annual fee. I never received the card and, upon calling them multiple times, eventually found out I wouldn't receive the card until I went to a branch with proof of residency. As there was a convenient nearby branch, I canceled the card and had the {$95.00} annual fee reversed by an agent via telephone. I later discovered that the fee hadn't actually been reversed and that I was charged a {$40.00} late fee as well. I was not made aware of this until calling back and once again asking them to reverse both fees, since I never received the card. 

The day after I called to reverse the incorrect fee a second time, they reported me for a late payment that drastically reduced my credit score with all three agencies. I called and emailed to have this late payment reversed but received no response. 

This was an illegitimate annual fee as I never received the card. In addition, I was told the fee was reversed before payment was due. I also wasn't notified that the fee was still outstanding until it was basically too late to avoid a late payment report to the credit agencies when no payment was actually due. The fact that the fee was reversed ( twice ) supports no payment was actually owed. 

It was horrible dealing with this bank and very difficult to reach the correct department to resolve an issue they created by approving a card and charging it then not actually mailing it. Insult to injury, they ruined my XXXX credit score due to an illegitimate charge that I was told had been reversed.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear PORTFOLIO, I am writing to address a blatant violation regarding the unauthorized reporting of information to my credit report, as confirmed by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) under Sections 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ), 1681c ( a ) ( 2 ), and 1681s-2 ( a ), and the Missouri Credit Reporting Act. 

It has unequivocally come to my attention that PORTFOLIO has already engaged in unauthorized reporting to my credit report without obtaining my explicit consent. Federal law, as outlined in the FCRA, explicitly mandates that the consent of the consumer is a non-negotiable requirement for such reporting activities under Section 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ). 

In addition to federal law, Missouri state law provides specific protections for consumers regarding credit reporting. These laws emphasize the necessity of consumer consent for credit reporting and establish clear guidelines for the fair reporting of consumer credit information. 

I assert with unwavering certainty that I have not provided consent for PORTFOLIO to report any information to my credit report. This undeniable lack of explicit permission constitutes a blatant violation of my rights, resulting in potential damage to my creditworthiness and an unequivocal disregard for federal and state laws. 
I demand, with the utmost certainty, that PORTFOLIO immediately ceases any further reporting of information to my credit report without obtaining my explicit consent, as mandated by Section 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ) of the FCRA and the Missouri Credit Reporting Act. Failure to comply within the stipulated 30-day timeframe will be viewed as willful noncompliance, subject to penalties under applicable laws, including identity fraud laws. 

I emphasize that obtaining consent is not a discretionary choice but a legal obligation under these specific sections of the FCRA and Missouri state law. This is not a negotiation ; it is a demand for compliance with both federal and state regulations, protecting consumers like myself from unauthorized and damaging credit reporting. 

I anticipate your immediate attention to this matter and expect that PORTFOLIO will promptly rectify these egregious violations, respecting my rights under federal and state laws. 

Done in good faith.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint because a debt collector from Reliant Capital Solutions violated my rights under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). On XX/XX/year> at XXXX, I informed the debt collector XXXX XXXX I was disputing the debt in question and that I had sent a formal dispute letter, which they should receive by [ Expected Arrival Date, e.g., XX/XX/XXXX ]. 

Despite my clear communication, the debt collector attempted to coerce me into discussing the contents of my dispute letter over the phone, which I am not legally obligated to do. When I refused, they threatened to mark my account as a refusal to pay and report this to the credit bureaus, even though the formal dispute had already been initiated. 

These actions comprise an unlawful attempt to intimidate me and violate my rights under the FDCPA, particularly the provisions that prevent debt XXXXollectors from taking adverse actions against a consumer without resolving a disputed debt. The collectors threat to report my account as a refusal to pay, despite my formal dispute, also violates my right to a fair debt resolution process and the protections afforded to me under 12 C.F.R. 1026.13 ( d ) ( 1 ) and 15 U.S. Code 1692e.

Moreover, I started receiving calls from this debt collector and, although I had been making regular payments, I realized that I had never received any statement balance or information on how much I owed or to whom I was making these payments. Concerned about this lack of transparency, I contacted the debt collector to inquire about the address where they had been sending my statements. To my shock, they informed me that they had just sent a statement to an address that was incorrectan address I have never lived at before. 

the debt collector has been sending mail containing my personal and financial information to the wrong address, despite me providing my correct address multiple times. This breach of cybersecurity is deeply concerning, as I do not know what sensitive information was included in the misdirected mail, and the agency has confirmed that they sent these communications to the incorrect addresses. Under the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ), financial institutions are required to ensure the security and confidentiality of consumer information, and this careless handling of my data is a clear violation of that law.

Furthermore, the debt collector provided misleading information regarding the reporting of my debt to the credit bureaus. Before this debt appeared on my credit report, I was never notified or informed that this would happen. I had been making regular payments to this collection agency, under the impression that doing so would prevent the debt from being reported to the credit bureaus. However, the debt suddenly appeared on my credit report without any prior notice. This constitutes a deceptive practice, as I was misled into believing that my payments would keep the debt off my credit report, which was not the case.

Under the FDCPA, 15 U.S. Code 1692e ( 10 ) prohibits the use of any false, deceptive, or misleading representation or means in connection with the collection of any debt. The debt collectors failure to inform me that my debt would be reported to the credit bureaus despite my payments is a clear violation of this provision.

I request that Reliant Capital Solutions be investigated for these violations, and that all negative reporting associated with this account be removed from my credit report. Additionally, I seek assurance that the agency will cease any further collection efforts on this disputed debt until the matter is fully resolved.

I called on XX/XX/XXXX after reading the email and again was told my the agent that I can initiate the opening of the account and again it would take 5-10 business days for an account specialist to review the account. The call dropped due to me being at work needing to take an elevator and losing signal. I came to know the account was closed on Sunday, XX/XX/2024. A letter was generated and dated XX/XX/2024. I received the letter in the mail on XX/XX/2024. My complaint is how can you execute an action on the account without notifying me in advance of the action? If the account and all of my other lines of credit are in excellent condition, why would Citibank not provide me an opportunity to avoid the account being closed? Why is my other Citibank credit card account still open and active when I haven't used that card in over 15 months as well? I do not understand the bias, that lack of communication nor the inconsistent information being told to me verbally, in writing and email. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports

Consumer complaint narrative:
15 U.S. Code 1692c - Communication in connection with debt collection ( a ) CoMMUnication WitH tHe conSUMeR GeneRallY Without the prior consent of the consumer given directly to the debt collector or the express permission of a court of competent jurisdiction, a debt collector may not communicate with a consumer in connection with the collection of any debt ( c ) CeaSinG coMMUnication If a consumer notifies a debt collector in writing that the consumer refuses to pay a debt or that the consumer wishes the debt collector to cease further communication with the consumer, the debt collector shall not communicate further with the consumer with respect to such debt, except ( 1 ) to advise the consumer that the debt collectors further efforts are being terminated ; ( 2 ) to notify the consumer that the debt collector or creditor may invoke specified remedies which are ordinarily invoked by such debt collector or creditor ; or ( 3 ) where applicable, to notify the consumer that the debt collector or creditor intends to invoke a specified remedy.

If such notice from the consumer is made by mail, notification shall be complete upon receipt.

A debt collector may not engage in any conduct the natural consequence of which is to harass, oppress, or abuse any person in connection with the collection of a debt. Without limiting the general application of the foregoing, the following conduct is a violation of this section : ( 1 ) The use or threat of use of violence or other criminal means to harm the physical person, reputation, or property of any person. 
( 2 ) The use of obscene or profane language or language the natural consequence of which is to abuse the hearer or reader.

( 3 ) The publication of a list of consumers who allegedly refuse to pay debts, except to a consumer reporting agency or to persons meeting the requirements of section 1681a ( f ) or 1681b ( 3 ) [ 1 ] of this title.

( 4 ) The advertisement for sale of any debt to coerce payment of the debt.

( 5 ) Causing a telephone to ring or engaging any person in telephone conversation repeatedly or continuously with intent to annoy, abuse, or harass any person at the called number.

( 6 ) Except as provided in section 1692b of this title, the placement of telephone calls without meaningful disclosure of the callers identity. 
( Pub. XXXX XXXX, title XXXX, XXXX, as added Pub. XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. XXXX. ) I have not supplied proof under the doctrine of estoppel by silence, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( mo ) XXXX XXXX XXXX, I presume that no proof of the alleged debt, nor therefore any such debt, in fact therefor exists pursuant to 18 USC 8, L owe no debt, this company is violation my consumer right to privacy pursuant to 15 USC 1681-B2 company has no permission to report my information per 15 USC 16814 .

Product: Mortgage
Sub-issue: Trying to communicate with the company to fix an issue related to modification, forbearance, short sale, deed-in-lieu, bankruptcy, or foreclosure
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to file a complaint against PHH Mortgage regarding their handling of my mortgage assistance request. I believe their actions constitute violations of the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act ( RESPA ).

Summary of Issues : 1. Inadequate Response to Mortgage Assistance Request : - I submitted a complete application ( Borrower Response Package ) to PHH Mortgage after my home was severely damaged due to a disaster. Despite this, PHH denied our claim for mortgage assistance without properly reviewing all the facts or contacting me to discuss the situation.

- I made multiple attempts to communicate with PHH, specifically requesting that the assigned representative, XXXX XXXX, contact me to discuss my hardship. Despite emailing several times and requesting callbacks on XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, I never received a response. 

2. Inappropriate Alternative Offered : - When I eventually spoke to someone in the loss mitigation department on XX/XX/XXXX, the only assistance offered was a home equity line of credit. I felt this was grossly inappropriate, as it seemed like PHH was more interested in profiting from a loan with a higher interest rate rather than providing genuine assistance to help me stay in my home.

3. Lack of Knowledge and Failure to Review : - The representative I spoke with appeared to lack knowledge about loss mitigation options. When I inquired about a forbearance, the representative was unfamiliar with the term.

- I also requested that PHH review our application with XXXX XXXX, the investor of our mortgage, but this was never done.

4. Misleading and Inaccurate Communication : - On XX/XX/XXXX, I received a letter from PHH stating that they would not issue a lender-placed insurance policy, which I never requested. They never explained what this was or why they were doing it.

The letter also claimed that PHH 's research suggested our insurance claim would be denied, even though it was never submitted to the insurance carrier. It is unclear how they could predict this outcome without submitting the claim.

5. Poor Communication and Reassignment : - Throughout this process, PHH has failed to maintain adequate communication. Despite numerous requests, I have never spoken to my assigned account representative. The only communication I have received from PHH has been generic letters that do not indicate any real evaluation of my situation.

- Furthermore, PHH recently reassigned us to a new representative, who has also failed to reach out or respond to any emails or phone calls.

Request for Action : I respectfully request that the CFPB investigate PHH Mortgage for their handling of my mortgage assistance request and their potential violations of RESPA. I believe their failure to properly review my application, provide appropriate assistance, and maintain communication constitutes a breach of their obligations under RESPA.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

NOTICE TO AGENT IS NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL NOTICE TO PRINCAL IS NOTICE TO AGENT You are furnishing inaccurate and incorrect information to the consumer reporting agencies.

You and your inaccurate reporting have damaged my livelihood.

15 U.S. Code 1681s2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( A ) Reporting information with actual knowledge of errors A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Duty : a moral or legal obligation ; a responsibility Accurate : correct in all details ; exact.

PROHIBITION : a law or regulation forbidding something As Defined by The IRS Even if you didn't receive a Form 1099-C, you must report canceled debt as gross income on your tax return.

The IRS Clearly defines a charge off as Gross or Ordinary income, INCOME DOES NOT GET REPORTED ON THE CONSUMER REPORT which in fact makes your reporting of this account inaccurate!

By Definition The IRS Clearly says a Cancelled debt or Charge off is Income. The reporting of this account as a debt is in accurate.

15 USC 1681 s-2 Says you XYZ company are a furnisher of information to a consumer reporting agency.

You ARE PROHIBITED BY LAW to furnish inaccurate information. I demand you to Cease and Desist the reporting of incorrect/ in accurate information immediately.

15 USC 1681 s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate You are hereby put on NOTICE that you are furnishing incorrect inaccurate information.

The lender must file Form 1099-C and send you a copy if the amount of debt canceled is {$600.00} or more and the lender is a financial institution, credit union , federal government agency, or other applicable entity as discussed earlier in chapter 1.

The above paragraph is taken directly from the IRS 2021 publication.

SEND ME MY FORM 1099-C that you should have sent when you Filled the account as a canceled debt.

My Address is listed below!

15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate ; and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate.

In conclusion I have shown you and you have been put on notice that you are reporting inaccurate information. The information is, in fact, inaccurate.

The continued reporting of this inaccurate information is a clear violation of the Law 15 USC 1681 s-2 of your responsibilities as a furnisher of information.

You have caused me and my family severe harm due to your negligence and inaccurate reporting. This is a final opportunity to Cure and DELETE This Erroneous, inaccurate account from my Consumer report.

YOU HAVE 10 Calendar days to DELETE THIS ACOOUNT FROM MY CONSUMER REPORTS!

Consumer complaint narrative:

Specialized Loan Servicing was my mortgage servicer but the communication that was received made it seem like the same was changed to Shellpoint which was only going to be payment processor. Now it seems the company name is Shellpoint Mortgage. In XX/XX/year> XXXX pymts were stopped without any notice. At the time was XXXX was attempting to work with SSXXXXI which was denied but currently in reconsideration. My mortgage payments are increasing due to mortgage insurance and taxes that are making it difficult to pay currently with one income. Im attempting to apply for modification and the documentation request from Shellpoint seems unfair. The following is documentation needed to be considered for modification. I dont know reasoning for some of documentation it doesnt pertain to my home. The Borrower Assistance Form application states that I didnt need any documentation for loss of income. 

. Once you have sent us all forms and documentation, we will conduct our review and your Single Point of Contact, XXXX XXXX, will tell you if any additional documents may still be needed. Once we have everything from you, your application will be considered " complete '' and ready for a decision. You will receive written notification of our decision. 
Document Type + Status XXXX Complete Bank Statemen -Not Complete Last month statement was completed uploaded Borrower Assistance Form-Complete Buyers Proof of Funds Not Received Contract Not Received Dodd-Frank Certification FormPending Review A HOA Dues Not Received HUD-1 Not Received Listing Agreement Not Received MLS Listing Not Received Pay Stubs Not Complete * Last months uploaded Website states for LOSS Mitigation. Q3 - What paperwork do I need to send you so I can get a loss-mitigation evaluation ( also called a " workout '' )? 
Answer : Here 's a list of the basic documents we need to take you through our loss mitigation process. Note : Depending on your specific situation, we may need other documents as well : IRS Form 4506-C ( Request for Copy of Tax Return ). Complete and sign. You can download this form from our website. 
Two paystubs. Do you earn a paycheck? If so, provide copies of your two most recent paystubs that show year-to-date earnings. 
Profit/loss statement. Are you self-employed? If so, provide a copy of your most recent quarterly or year-to-date profit/loss statement. 
Bank statements. Send us a copy of your two most recent personal bank statements for all of your bank accounts. 
Include a letter that explains any non-paycheck deposits or transfers of {$1000.00} or more in the last six months. 
HOA dues. Provide proof of payment for any homeowner association dues. 
Don't wait until you have every document in hand before you start sending items to us-start by sending us what you have. Call our Customer Care Team at XXXX for instructions on uploading ( electronically sending ) documents to us. 
After we receive your documents, we'll assign one of our trained mortgage professionals to you as your single point of contact ( SPOC ) during your loss-mitigation evaluation. Your SPOC will work closely with you to develop the best possible solution for you and your family.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing a complaint against World Acceptance Corporation, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX for inaccurate reporting of a charged-off debt, violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ), the Privacy Act of 1974, and the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( GLBA ). 

World Acceptance Corporation has reported a charged-off debt to XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX on my credit report. This is in violation of the FDCPA, which states that when an account is more than 180 days past due, it must generally be charged off. Despite being charged off, World Acceptance Corporation has failed to provide me with a 1099-C form, as required by IRS code 4681. 

World Acceptance Corporation has violated the FCRA ( 15 US. .Code 1681s2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies ) by reporting inaccurate information to the credit bureaus. Specifically, they have reported the charged-off debt without having reasonable cause to believe that the information is accurate. This has severely affected my overall score and financial stability. 
World Acceptance Corporation actions also violate the Consumer Financial Protection Act ( CFPA ) - 12 CFR 31.3 and the CFPA 's prohibition against unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts or practices. By continuing to report the charged-off account as a debt, World Acceptance Corporation is engaging in deceptive conduct that harms consumers. 

Furthermore, World Acceptance Corporation has violated my rights under the Privacy Act of 1974. The Privacy Act of 1974, as amended, 5 U.S.C. 552a, establishes a code of fair information practices that governs the collection, maintenance, use, and dissemination of information about individuals that is maintained in systems of records by federal agencies. A system of records is a group of records under the control of an agency from which information is retrieved by the name of the individual or by some identifier assigned to the individual. The Privacy Act prohibits the disclosure of a record about an individual from a system of records absent the written consent of the individual, unless the disclosure is pursuant to one of twelve statutory exceptions. World Acceptance Corporation improperly disclosed my personal information to credit reporting agencies, specifically XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. 

Additionally, World Acceptance Corporation has violated the GLBA ( 15 U.S.C. 6802, also known as section 502 ( b ) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ) by failing to provide me with a clear and conspicuous notice of their intent to share my nonpublic personal information with nonaffiliated third parties, such as XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. This coincides with 16 CFR 313.7 ( Form of opt out notice to consumers ; opt out methods ) 16 CFR 313.10 ( Limits on disclosure of non-public personal information to nonaffiliated third parties ) and 248.124 ( Reasonable opportunity to opt out ). 

Supporting Documentation : Credit Reports Opt Out Letter to World Acceptance Corporation that was ignored FDCPA Documentation concerning charge-off statuses Requested Relief : I request that the CFPB investigate this matter and take appropriate action against World Acceptance Corporation World Acceptance Corporation XXXX XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. I seek the removal of the inaccurate information from my credit report, as well as compensation deemed appropriate and upholding the law per violation committed. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Jefferson Capital Systems has continued to report an alleged debt on my credit report despite my formal dispute and request for a cease and desist. I have clearly communicated that I dispute the debt and that their continued reporting constitutes a form of communication under the FDCPA. 

In XXXX XXXX XXXX, 514 U.S. 291 ( 1995 ), the United States Supreme Court affirmed that the FDCPA broadly covers all communications related to the collection of a debt. This includes communications made through consumer reporting, as defined by the FDCPA. 

Furthermore, under 12 U.S.C. 5531, the CFPB is empowered to take action against entities engaging in unfair, deceptive, or abusive acts or practices. By continuing to report this disputed debt, Jefferson Capital Systems is engaging in an unfair practice, causing harm to my credit reputation and financial standing.

Duty : a moral or legal obligation ; a responsibility Accurate : correct in all details ; exact. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Says you XXXX company are a furnisher of information to a consumer reporting agency. 
You ARE PROHIBITED BY LAW to furnish inaccurate information. I demand you to Cease and Desist the reporting of incorrect/ in accurate information immediately. 
15 USC 1681 s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate You are hereby put on NOTICE that you are furnishing incorrect inaccurate information. 

The lender must file Form XXXX and send you a copy if the amount of debt canceled is {$XXXX} or more and the lender is a financial institution, credit union XXXX federal government agency, or other applicable entity as discussed earlier in chapter XXXX. 
The above paragraph is taken directly from the IRS XXXX  publication. 
SEND ME MY FORM XXXX that you should have sent when you Filled the account as a canceled debt.

My Address is listed below!

15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate ; and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate. 

In conclusion I have shown you and you have been put on notice that you are reporting inaccurate information. The information is, in fact, inaccurate.

The continued reporting of this inaccurate information is a clear violation of the Law 15 USC 1681 s-2 of your responsibilities as a furnisher of information.

You have caused me and my family severe harm due to your negligence and inaccurate reporting. This is a final opportunity to Cure and DELETE This Erroneous, inaccurate account from my Consumer repor
t.

YOU HAVE XXXX Calendar days to DELETE THIS ACOOUNT FROM MY CONSUMER REPORTS!

Product: Debt collection
Sub-issue: Didn't receive notice of right to dispute
Consumer complaint narrative:
I filed a dispute with Jefferson Capital Systems for violation of FDCPA and they did not respond to my dispute nor provided me with any information on my rights to dispute before adding this collection to my consumer report. 

( a ) Notice of debt ; contents Within five days after the initial communication with a consumer in connection with the collection of any debt, a debt collector shall, unless the following information is contained in the initial communication or the consumer has paid the debt, send the consumer a written notice containing ( 1 ) the amount of the debt ; ( 2 ) the name of the creditor to whom the debt is owed ; ( 3 ) a statement that unless the consumer, within thirty days after receipt of the notice, disputes the validity of the debt, or any portion thereof, the debt will be assumed to be valid by the debt collector ; ( 4 ) a statement that if the consumer notifies the debt collector in writing within the thirty-day period that the debt, or any portion thereof, is disputed, the debt collector will obtain verification of the debt or a copy of a judgment against the consumer and a copy of such verification or judgment will be mailed to the consumer by the debt collector ; and ( 5 ) a statement that, upon the consumers written request within the thirty-day period, the debt collector will provide the consumer with the name and address of the original creditor, if different from the current creditor.

( b ) Disputed debts If the consumer notifies the debt collector in writing within the thirty-day period described in subsection ( a ) that the debt, or any portion thereof, is disputed, or that the consumer requests the name and address of the original creditor, the debt collector shall cease collection of the debt, or any disputed portion thereof, until the debt collector obtains verification of the debt or a copy of a judgment, or the name and address of the original creditor, and a copy of such verification or judgment, or name and address of the original creditor, is mailed to the consumer by the debt collector. Collection activities and communications that do not otherwise violate this subchapter may continue during the 30-day period referred to in subsection ( a ) unless the consumer has notified the debt collector in writing that the debt, or any portion of the debt, is disputed or that the consumer requests the name and address of the original creditor. Any collection activities and communication during the 30-day period may not overshadow or be inconsistent with the disclosure of the consumers right to dispute the debt or request the name and address of the original creditor.

( c ) Admission of liability The failure of a consumer to dispute the validity of a debt under this section may not be construed by any court as an admission of liability by the consumer.

( d ) Legal pleadings A communication in the form of a formal pleading in a civil action shall not be treated as an initial communication for purposes of subsection ( a ).

( e ) Notice provisions The sending or delivery of any form or notice which does not relate to the collection of a debt and is expressly required by title 26, title V of Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act [ 15 U.S.C. 6801 et seq. ], or any provision of Federal or State law relating to notice of data security breach or privacy, or any regulation prescribed under any such provision of law, shall not be treated as an initial communication in connection with debt collection for purposes of this section.

Product: Debt collection
Issue: Took or threatened to take negative or legal action
Sub-issue: Threatened or suggested your credit would be damaged
Consumer complaint narrative: As a federally protected consumer I'm seeking proof of the alleged debt, under the doctrine of estoppel by silence, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, I may presume that no proof of the alleged debt, nor therefore any such debt, in fact exists. In a good faith effort to resolve this matter amicably, I demand for proof of the debt, specifically the alleged contract or other instrument bearing my signature in wet ink, as well as proof of your authority in this matter. Absent such proof, you must terminate this collection action and correct any erroneous reports of this debt as mine. For the record, I state again that as I have no account with you, nor am I your customer, nor have I entered into a contract with you, I must ask for the following information : 1 ) Please evidence your authorization under 15 USC 1692 ( e ) 15 USC 1692 ( f ) and USC 1692 ( g ) in this alleged matter. 2 ) What is your authorization of law for your collection of information? 3 ) What is your authorization of law for your collection of this alleged debt? 4 ) Please evidence your authorization to do business or operate in the state. 5 ) Please provide proof of the alleged debt, including specifically the alleged contract or other instrument bearing my wet signature. You have 7 days of this notice to respond. Your failure to respond, on point, in writing, hand signed, and in a timely manner, will work as a waiver to any and all of your claims in this matter, and will entitle me to presume that you sent your letter in error, and that this matter is permanently closed. Your continued silence is unacceptable. Either provide the proof or correct the record to remove the invalid debt from my credit files with the three-primary credit-reporting agencies. You are currently in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act and the Fair Debt Collection Act. I can't obtain housing or employment due to the violations on my credit file. Failure to respond within 7 days of this letter will begin my small claims action against your company. I will be seeking { {$5000.00} } in damages for the following : 1 ) Defamation 2 ) Negligent Enablement of Identity Fraud 3 ) Violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act After obtaining the judgment against your company, I will obtain a Writ of Execution from the Sheriffs office in your county and I will begin the process of attaching property or funds to satisfy the judgment. For the purposes of 15 USC 1692 et seq., this Notice has the same effect as a dispute to the validity of the alleged debt and a dispute to the validity of your claims. This Notice is an attempt to correct your records, and any information received from you will be collected as evidence should any further action be necessary. This is a request for information only, and is not a statement, election, or waiver of status.

on XX/XX/year> I recieved several phone calls saying from Credit Karma and that they needed me to press one for yes 2 for no about a XXXX transaction taking place. I didn't want to press anything as I felt it was a scam. So I called Credit Karma and was informed that they had not tried to call me, nor was anyone trying to make a transaction. 
on XXXX  XX/XX/year> I picked up XXXX XXXX and was informed my Credit Karma Money card was declined. As I knew I had plenty of money on it I checked my credit Karma account and found that my accounts were FROZEN! I called and was told only that it was for my protection. I was livid as I needed to be able to access the money. I was told that on XX/XX/year> I could go to an ATM and withdraw from my card, which I did, XXXX. 
on the XXXX my account was unfrozen. On the evening of the XXXX I got a push notification on my phone that the transfer of XXXX from my savings to my Spend account had been completed... I did not authorize this so I immediately called credit Karma only to be asked if I had changed my phone number. I had NOT and still can not understand how they allowed someone to change my phone number when they wouldn't even TALK to me without sending me a link and my sending them my drivers license, front and back, as well as a selfie of myself holding the drivers license! By the time I got through over XXXX had been removed from my money account by ATM transactions and purchases at XXXX. THIS took place while I was on the phone! 
Credit Karma froze my money card, and i asked them to freeze my checking account until they got my stolen money back. Now there is a screen with the WRONG phone number on it and they ask me to verify that it's my number, it isn't! I have had the same phone number since the day I opened Credit Karma. I asked today why they won't put MY phone number back, and I am told they are working on it. Shouldn't my phone number be back on there as well as asking me to change my password? Isn't Credit Karma supposed to protect us? How did they allow a hacker to come into my account and compromise it by changing MY INFORMATION. Now I am told it may be 90 days! I would like to get all of the money out of my accounts before Credit Karma allows it to happen again!

NOTICE TO AGENT IS NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL NOTICE TO PRINCAL IS NOTICE TO AGENT You Discover Bank are furnishing inaccurate and incorrect information to the consumer reporting agencies. 

The reporting of such inaccurate information has caused severe damage to my character, my reputation, my general mode of living and my ability to obtain credit for personal and house purposes. 

You and your inaccurate reporting have damaged my livelihood. 

15 U.S. Code 16815-2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( A ) Reporting information with actual knowledge of errors A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 

Duty : a moral or legal obligation ; a responsibility Accurate : correct in all details ; exact. 

PROHIBITION : a law or regulation forbidding something As Defined by The IRS Even if you didn't receive a Form 1099-C, you must report canceled debt as gross income on your tax return.

The IRS Clearly defines a charge off as Gross or Ordinary income, INCOME DOES NOT GET REPORTED ON THE CONSUMER REPORT which in fact makes your reporting of this account inaccurate. 

By Definition The IRS Clearly says a Cancelled or Charge off is Income. The reporting of this account as a debt is in accurate.

15 USC 1681 s-2 Says you Discover Bank are a furnisher of information to a consumer reporting agency. 

You ARE PROHIBITED BY LAW to furnish inaccurate information. I demand you to cease and Desist the reporting of incorrect in accurate information immediately. 

15 USC 1681 5-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate You are hereby put on NOTICE that you are furnishing incorrect inaccurate information. 
The lender must file Form 1099-C and send you a copy if the amount of debt canceled is {$600.00} or more and the lender is a financial institution, credit union , federal government agency, or other applicable entity as discussed earlier in XXXX XXXX 

The above paragraph is taken directly from the IRS 2024 publication. 

SEND ME MY FORM 1099-C that you should have sent when you filled the account as a canceled debt. 

15 U.S. Code 16815-2 ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if- A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if- ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate ; and ( il ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate. 

In conclusion I have shown you and you have been put on notice that you are reporting inaccurate information. 

The information is, in fact, inaccurate. 

The continued reporting of this inaccurate information is a clear violation of the Law 15 USC 1681 s-2 of your responsibilities as a furnisher of information. 

You have caused me and my family severe harm due to your negligence and inaccurate reporting. This is a final opportunity to Cure and DELETE This Erroneous, inaccurate account from my Consumer report. 

YOU HAVE XXXX Calendar days to DELETE THIS ACCOUNT FROM MY CONSUMER REPORTS! 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX GA XXXX
Company: CAPITAL ONE, NATIONAL ASSOCIATION - GREENWOOD DELAWARE BRANCH

Product: Debt collection
Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Sub-issue: Debt was result of identity theft
Consumer complaint narrative:
I'll update the letter to include the issue with XXXX and how they are allegedly violating your rights by repeatedly re-inserting the collection account on your consumer report. 

-- - XXXX XXXX XXXXConsumer Financial Protection BureauXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, IA XXXX XXXX : XXXX Dispute of Collection Account - Violation of Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) **To Whom It May Concern : ** I am writing to formally dispute a collection account that was recently added to my credit report between XX/XX/year>, and XX/XX/year>, by the collection agency XXXX XXXX XXXX The original creditor listed for this account is XXXX XXXX XXXX. I believe this collection account has been reported in violation of several pro

visions under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). **Specific Violations : ** 1. **Unauthorized Access and Reporting ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ) : ** Under FCRA, my consumer report can only be accessed for permissible purposes. This collection account does not have a permissible purpose, and I did not authorize the inclusion of this account on my credit report. 

2. **Communication Restrictions ( 15 U.S.C. 1692c ) : ** The FDCPA prohibits debt collectors from communicating with third parties about my debt without my consent. Any communication or reporting of this debt without my explicit consent is a violation.

3. **Prohibition Against Selling Disputed Debts ( 15 U.S.C. 1692e ) : ** It has come to my attention that the debt associated with this collection account has been sold to another debt collector. This practice is deceptive and violates the FDCPA, specifically 15 U.S.C. 1692e, which prohibits any false, deceptive, or misleading representation concerning the collection of a debt.

4. **Validation of Debt ( 15 U.S.C. 1692g ) : ** Under FDCPA, I have the right to request validation of this debt. I have not been provided with any such validation, and the debt has been sold, further complicating the matter. This lack of validation and subsequent sale is a direct violation of my rights.

5. **Reinvestigation of Disputed Information ( 15 U.S.C . 1681i ) : ** Under FCRA, if disputed information is reported to a credit reporting agency, the agency is required to conduct a reinvestigation. This collection account was added without proper investigation, and I demand a reinvestigation and removal of this account.

**Additional Violation by TransUnion : ** TransUnion has repeatedly reinserted this collection account into my credit report after its removal, which is a clear violation of FCRA. Under **15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ( B ) **, a credit reporting agency can not reinsert previously deleted information without notifying the consumer and providing documentation that the information is accurate. This repeated re-insertion without proper notification or validation is unlawful and must be addressed immediately.

Given these clear violations of federal law, I request the immediate removal of this collection account from my credit report. I also request that any subsequent debt collector be informed of this dispute and that any further attempts to collect or report this debt be ceased.

Please provide me with written confirmation of the actions taken in response to this dispute within 30 days, as required by law.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

**Sincerely, ** XXXX XXXX XXXX-

Consumer complaint narrative: As per the guidance from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) the documents needed are a picture ID, a bill, and a letter from an advocacy group helping me due to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, which falls under XXXX  according to Trafficking-Debt Final Rule 1002.142 ( b ) ( 4 ) -5 -- 1002.142 ( b ) ( 7 ). I kindly request that you block this information from my credit report within four business days, pursuant to section 605C of the Fair Credit Reporting Act. Consumer complaint narrative:
I filed a dispute with Contract Callers Inc for violation of FDCPA and they did not respond to my dispute nor provided me with information on my rights to dispute before added this collection to mu consumer report. 
( a ) Notice of debt ; contents Within XXXX days after the initial communication with a consumer in connection with the collection of any debt, a debt collector shall, unless the following information is contained in the initial communication or the consumer has paid the debt, send the consumer a written notice containing ( XXXX ) the amount of the debt ; ( XXXX ) the name of the creditor to whom the debt is owed ; ( XXXX ) a statement that unless the consumer, within XXXX days after receipt of the notice, disputes the validity of the debt, or any portion thereof, the debt will be assumed to be valid by the debt collector ; ( XXXX ) a statement that if the consumer notifies the debt collector in writing within the thirty-day period that the debt, or any portion thereof, is disputed, the debt collector will obtain verification of the debt or a copy of a judgment against the consumer and a copy of such verification or judgment will be mailed to the consumer by the debt collector ; and ( XXXX ) a statement that, upon the consumers written request within the thirty-day period, the debt collector will provide the consumer with the name and address of the original creditor, if different from the current creditor. 
( b ) Disputed debts If the consumer notifies the debt collector in writing within the thirty-day period described in subsection ( a ) that the debt, or any portion thereof, is disputed, or that the consumer requests the name and address of the original creditor, the debt collector shall cease collection of the debt, or any disputed portion thereof, until the debt collector obtains verification of the debt or a copy of a judgment, or the name and address of the original creditor, and a copy of such verification or judgment, or name and address of the original creditor, is mailed to the consumer by the debt collector. XXXX activities and communications that do not otherwise violate this subchapter XXXX continue during the XXXX period referred to in subsection ( a ) unless the consumer has notified the debt collector in writing that the debt, or any portion of the debt, is disputed or that the consumer requests the name and address of the original creditor. Any collection activities and communication during the XXXX period XXXX not overshadow or be inconsistent with the disclosure of the consumers right to dispute the debt or request the name and address of the original creditor. 

( c ) Admission of liability The failure of a consumer to dispute the validity of a debt under this section XXXX not be construed by any court as an admission of liability by the consumer. 

( d ) Legal pleadings A communication in the form of a formal pleading in a civil action shall not be treated as an initial communication for purposes of subsection ( a ). 

( XXXX ) Notice provisions The sending or delivery of any form or notice which does not relate to the collection of a debt and is expressly required by title 26, title V of Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act [ 15 U.S.C. 6801 et seq. ], or any provision of Federal or State law relating to notice of data security breach or privacy, or any regulation prescribed under any such provision of law, shall not be treated as an initial communication in connection with debt collection for purposes of this section.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear LVNV FUNDING, I am writing to address a blatant violation regarding the unauthorized reporting of information to my credit report, as confirmed by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) under Sections 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ), 1681c ( a ) ( 2 ), and 1681s-2 ( a ), and the Missouri Credit Reporting Act.

It has unequivocally come to my attention that LVNV FUNDING has already engaged in unauthorized reporting to my credit report without obtaining my explicit consent. Federal law, as outlined in the FCRA, explicitly mandates that the consent of the consumer is a non-negotiable requirement for such reporting activities under Section 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ).

In addition to federal law, Missouri state law provides specific protections for consumers regarding credit reporting. These laws emphasize the necessity of consumer consent for credit reporting and establish clear guidelines for the fair reporting of consumer credit information.

I assert with unwavering certainty that I have not provided consent for LVNV FUNDING to report any information to my credit report. This undeniable lack of explicit permission constitutes a blatant violation of my rights, resulting in potential damage to my creditworthiness and an unequivocal disregard for federal and state laws.

I demand, with the utmost certainty, that LVNV FUNDING immediately ceases any further reporting of information to my credit report without obtaining my explicit consent, as mandated by Section 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ) of the FCRA and the Missouri Credit Reporting Act. Failure to comply within the stipulated 30-day timeframe will be viewed as willful noncompliance, subject to penalties under applicable laws, including identity fraud laws.

I emphasize that obtaining consent is not a discretionary choice but a legal obligation under these specific sections of the FCRA and Missouri state law. This is not a negotiation ; it is a demand for compliance with both federal and state regulations, protecting consumers like myself from unauthorized and damaging credit reporting.

I anticipate your immediate attention to this matter and expect that LVNV FUNDING will promptly rectify these egregious violations, respecting my rights under federal and state laws.

Done in good faith.

Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX I received a credit alert from XXXX. It was advising of a drop in my credit score that was the result of a collections account being added to my credit report. 

I accessed my report and found the entry read Congress Collections, who was collecting a balance of {$770.00} on behalf of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I called the phone number provided in the collections entry and was advised that the service date involved was XX/XX/XXXX. The collection agency claimed to have sent documentation to my residence in XXXX but that was never received. Congress Collection provided their email for me to send a debt validation request ; two emails were sent requesting verification on XX/XX/XXXX. 

I contacted XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX who informed me that they show no previous past-due balance or any notation that a balance was sent to collections. They also provided the address of XXXX XXXX XXXX who is associated with their clinic. XXXX XXXX XXXX shows no current or past-due balance either. 

I was being seen in the aforementioned medical facilities as the result of an injury sustained in a car crash. The car crash resulted in litigation ( I was the plantiff ) and the litigation ended in a settlement, with the other involved party handling my medical bills. This visit would have been part of that settlement and presumably any balance due was handled by the other party 's insurance company. I contacted the law firm that handled my case to have them investigate on their end as well. 

I disputed this entry on XXXX and XXXX via their websites. Both bureaus closed the dispute stating the collection agency " certified '' that I owed the debt but the collection agency has yet to furnish anything to me showing the same. 

Based on the information received from the alleged creditor and my knowledge that the medical visit during that time frame was covered under my settlement, I do not believe that this debt is owed or is mine to pay.

Account Number : XXXX Dear LVNV Funding, LLC, I am writing to formally notify you to cease all collection activities regarding the above-referenced account. I dispute the validity of this debt and demand that you immediately stop all communication with me, as well as any attempts to collect this debt. 

Please be advised that under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), you are required to honor my request. Failure to do so may result in legal action against your company for violations of the FDCPA. 

I would like to bring to your attention the case of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX. XXXX XXXX, XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ). In this case, the court ruled that continued collection efforts after a valid cease and desist request can result in significant penalties, including statutory damages and the payment of attorneys fees. Your company is hereby notified that any further communication with me, outside of the exceptions provided by the FDCPA, will be considered harassment and a violation of my rights. 

Therefore, I demand that you : 1. Cease all communication with me regarding this debt. 
2. Refrain from reporting or continuing to report this debt to any credit reporting agencies. 
3. Ensure that any negative credit reporting related to this debt is promptly removed. 

Please confirm in writing within 30 days of receiving this letter that you have complied with my request. Any future contact from your company, aside from acknowledgment of compliance, will be met with legal action. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this serious matter.

Consumer complaint narrative: On XX/XX/year>2024 I ordered a computer part from a business in the local area. Business owner was adamant about me paying through cash app due to card reader being down. Did not want to pay cash so proceeded with electronic payment via cash app. Business owner assured us we would have the part within one week. After a week and a half he didnt deliver on the promised products and told us it was a miscommunication on his part. He initially ordered the wrong part, then he stated there were shipping delays. After speaking to him on XX/XX/XXXX he assured us he would have an answer on XX/XX/XXXX, whether it would be to provide us with our computer part or to give us another update on the shipping. He never answered our calls, so we went ahead and requested a refund via cash app, that was denied. We also tried to file a claim with our bank and that was denied. I have since exchanged emails with him back and forth and he is steadfast with the excuse that he uses a third party company to handle payments and cant pay me my money back. Ive asked him numerous times why he can't just send me the money back the same way I sent it to him with no avail. He will not provide me any proof that the transaction ever took place. He does numerous phone and electronics repairs in house and claims to use an online vendor to purchase parts from. We were comfortable using his services because he was reccomended by a friend and he was offering us a discount from a part he previously diagnosed as unrepairable. Due to paying through cash app, I would like them to consider giving me my money back since I have no other way of doing so.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I was recently laid off from my job and, while reviewing my recent transactions due to a separate issue with Chase, I noticed an unfamiliar charge from XXXX. I reached out to Chases claims department and confirmed that this transaction was unauthorized. To my surprise, I learned that unauthorized transactions with XXXX had been occurring since XXXX, which I had not been aware of. 

After resolving the initial dispute, I found a discrepancy in the refund amount. Upon further inquiry, I was informed that claims could only be filed within 60 days of the statement date. Unfortunately, many of the larger charges I initially flagged were beyond this 60-day window. 

There are still four other fraudulent charges totaling {$850.00} that I was unable to dispute because of this time limitation. 

I understand the 60-day rule, but I assure you that if I had been aware of these fraudulent charges sooner, I would have addressed them immediately. I discovered them while handling another issue, and I feel deeply violated by this situation. When I initially reached out to Chase, no one mentioned the 60-day restriction. I only learned about it when following up on the additional charges. Although I requested an exception, it was denied, with the explanation that I was informed of this policy when I opened my account nearly three years ago. 

I am asking for some understanding and compassion in this matter. I worked long hours in a demanding job and rarely checked my account, so the oversight was unintentional. I hope you can consider my situation and assist me in resolving this issue fairly.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear DISCOVERBANK, I am writing to address a blatant violation regarding the unauthorized reporting of information to my credit report, as confirmed by the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) under Sections 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ), 1681c ( a ) ( 2 ), and 1681s-2 ( a ), and the XXXX Credit Reporting Act. 

It has unequivocally come to my attention that DISCOVERBANK has already engaged in unauthorized reporting to my credit report without obtaining my explicit consent. Federal law, as outlined in the FCRA, explicitly mandates that the consent of the consumer is a non-negotiable requirement for such reporting activities under Section 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ).

In addition to federal law, Missouri state law provides specific protections for consumers regarding credit reporting. These laws emphasize the necessity of consumer consent for credit reporting and establish clear guidelines for the fair reporting of consumer credit information. 

I assert with unwavering certainty that I have not provided consent for DISCOVERBANK to report any information to my credit report. This undeniable lack of explicit permission constitutes a blatant violation of my rights, resulting in potential damage to my creditworthiness and an unequivocal disregard for federal and state laws. 
I demand, with the utmost certainty, that DISCOVERBANK immediately ceases any further reporting of information to my credit report without obtaining my explicit consent, as mandated by Section 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ) of the FCRA and the Missouri Credit Reporting Act. Failure to comply within the stipulated XXXX timeframe will be viewed as willful noncompliance, subject to penalties under applicable laws, including identity fraud laws. 

I emphasize that obtaining consent is not a discretionary choice but a legal obligation under these specific sections of the FCRA and Missouri state law. This is not a negotiation ; it is a demand for compliance with both federal and state regulations, protecting consumers like myself from unauthorized and damaging credit reporting. 

I anticipate your immediate attention to this matter and expect that DISCOVERBANK will promptly rectify these egregious violations, respecting my rights under federal and state laws. 

Done in good faith.
Company: CAPITAL ONE, NATIONAL ASSOCIATION - GREENWOOD DELAWARE BRANCH

Furthermore, we have the right to receive advanced notifications or alerts to action early and avoid the fee charges. It seems that banks are just waiting there for a chance that a consumer finally falls into their set-up trap so that they could enjoy charging fees recklessly! I hope the regulators would cancel such unreasonable penalty imposed from the bank side on consumers.

Product: Debt collection
Sub-issue: Didn't receive notice of right to dispute
Consumer complaint narrative:
I filed a dispute with Caine & Weiner for violation of FDCPA and they did not respond to my dispute nor provided me with any information on my rights to dispute before added this collection to my consumer report.

( a ) Notice of debt ; contents Within five days after the initial communication with a consumer in connection with the collection of any debt, a debt collector shall, unless the following information is contained in the initial communication or the consumer has paid the debt, send the consumer a written notice containing ( 1 ) the amount of the debt ; ( 2 ) the name of the creditor to whom the debt is owed ; ( 3 ) a statement that unless the consumer, within thirty days after receipt of the notice, disputes the validity of the debt, or any portion thereof, the debt will be assumed to be valid by the debt collector ; ( 4 ) a statement that if the consumer notifies the debt collector in writing within the thirty-day period that the debt, or any portion thereof, is disputed, the debt collector will obtain verification of the debt or a copy of a judgment against the consumer and a copy of such verification or judgment will be mailed to the consumer by the debt collector ; and ( 5 ) a statement that, upon the consumers written request within the thirty-day period, the debt collector will provide the consumer with the name and address of the original creditor, if different from the current creditor.

( b ) Disputed debts If the consumer notifies the debt collector in writing within the thirty-day period described in subsection ( a ) that the debt, or any portion thereof, is disputed, or that the consumer requests the name and address of the original creditor, the debt collector shall cease collection of the debt, or any disputed portion thereof, until the debt collector obtains verification of the debt or a copy of a judgment, or the name and address of the original creditor, and a copy of such verification or judgment, or name and address of the original creditor, is mailed to the consumer by the debt collector. Collection activities and communications that do not otherwise violate this subchapter may continue during the 30-day period referred to in subsection ( a ) unless the consumer has notified the debt collector in writing that the debt, or any portion of the debt, is disputed or that the consumer requests the name and address of the original creditor. Any collection activities and communication during the 30-day period may not overshadow or be inconsistent with the disclosure of the consumers right to dispute the debt or request the name and address of the original creditor.

( c ) Admission of liability The failure of a consumer to dispute the validity of a debt under this section may not be construed by any court as an admission of liability by the consumer.

( d ) Legal pleadings A communication in the form of a formal pleading in a civil action shall not be treated as an initial communication for purposes of subsection ( a ).

( e ) Notice provisions The sending or delivery of any form or notice which does not relate to the collection of a debt and is expressly required by title 26, title V of Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act [ 15 U.S.C. 6801 et seq. ], or any provision of Federal or State law relating to notice of data security breach or privacy, or any regulation prescribed under any such provision of law, shall not be treated as an initial communication in connection with debt collection for purposes of this section.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to express my deep frustration and anger regarding my recent experience with LexisNexis, a consumer reporting agency that I had never even heard of until they intruded into my life in the most unsettling way. All I was trying to do was shop for cheaper car insurance while diligently working on improving my credit scorea task that is hard enough without interference. However, what I discovered has left me outraged. 

Imagine my shock when I was informed by XXXX that they had obtained a report on me from LexisNexis. This report, which I had never authorized, detailed how many times I had shopped for car insurance this year. Let me be clear : I never shared this information with LexisNexis or any other third party. I was under the impression that I was simply looking at prices, browsing quotes, and gathering information. I had no idea that every click was being monitored, stored, and shared behind my back. 

But that wasnt the end of it. The report also contained details about my driving history. Again, I askhow did this information find its way into LexisNexis hands? I never gave them permission to collect or store such personal data. The fact that a company I have never interacted with can so easily compile and distribute such sensitive information without my consent is not just troublingits terrifying. 

What makes this situation even more infuriating is the impact it has had on my life. Since LexisNexis provided this unauthorized report to XXXX, I have noticed that 15 to 20 insurance companies now refuse to even provide me with a quote, let alone sell me a policy. I was just trying to find a more affordable option, and instead, Ive been effectively blacklisted, through no fault of my own. The system that was supposed to help me is now working against me, and it all leads back to LexisNexis. 

In an effort to understand how this could happen, I decided to order a consumer report on myself directly from LexisNexis. I provided them with all the necessary information : my full name, Social Security number, drivers license numbereverything they requested. Yet, in return, I received a letter stating that they couldnt identify any account associated with my name. This was not just confusingit was enraging. How is it that they couldnt find my account when I gave them all this personal information, but had no problem identifying me when XXXX requested my data? Whats even more bewildering is that XXXX doesnt have access to my Social Security number, yet LexisNexis had no trouble pulling together a report on me. 

Determined to get answers, I called LexisNexis, only to be told that I would need to provide the same personal information over the phone to verify my identity. I can not express how infuriating it was to hear that I needed to verify myself to a company that has been collecting my data without my consent for who knows how long. When I pressed the customer service representative on whether LexisNexis follows any data ethics practices, his response was chilling : " Im afraid I dont know what that is, '' followed by a blunt admission that " No, we just buy data from third parties ; we dont follow any data ethics premises. '' This entire experience has been nothing short of a nightmare. I feel violated, angry, and helpless. My privacy has been invaded, my personal information has been collected and shared without my consent, and now Im being penalized by insurance companies as a result. Its clear to me that LexisNexis operates with a complete disregard for consumer privacy and data ethics. 

I am filing this report with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) because this kind of behavior can not go unchecked. No company should be allowed to operate with such blatant disregard for the rights and privacy of consumers. I urge the CFPB to investigate LexisNexis and hold them accountable for their actions. This is not just about methis is about protecting every consumer from the reckless and unethical practices of companies like LexisNexis.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative: I am filing this complaint regarding a serious violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ), which prohibits conduct that harasses, oppresses, or abuses any person in connection with debt collection. An unknown third-party collection agency has reported an alleged debt from 2019 on my credit file, despite this debt having been previously disputed and removed. This action not only violates the FDCPA by harming my reputation, but also potentially infringes upon the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) by reporting inaccurate information. The reappearance of this removed debt suggests a failure to conduct proper investigations as required by the FCRA. Furthermore, I have no contract with this third-party agency, raising concerns about the legitimacy of their collection attempts. This situation may extend beyond mere regulatory violations into more serious territory. The coordinated effort to repeatedly report a removed debt could be indicative of a conspiracy to violate consumer protection laws. The attempt to collect on a debt with no legitimate claim, while damaging my credit report, may constitute a form of financial extortion. Additionally, the mishandling of my personal and financial information in this manner raises significant concerns about privacy violations and potential identity theft. I assert that these actions collectively represent a concerted effort to harass and coerce payment through improper means, causing undue harm to my financial standing and reputation. I demand an immediate investigation into these practices, the removal of this inaccurate information from my credit report, and cessation of all collection activities related to this alleged debt. I reserve the right to pursue all available legal remedies, including statutory damages under the FDCPA, actual damages for harm to my credit score and reputation, and any other applicable remedies under consumer protection and criminal laws.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Account information incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
I filed a dispute with Spring Oaks Capital LLC for violation of FDCPA and they did not respond to my dispute nor provided me with information on my rights to dispute before they added this collection to my consumer report.

( a ) Notice of debt ; contents Within five days after the initial communication with a consumer in connection with the collection of any debt, a debt collector shall, unless the following information is contained in the initial communication or the consumer has paid the debt, send the consumer a written notice containing ( 1 ) the amount of the debt ; ( 2 ) the name of the creditor to whom the debt is owed ; ( 3 ) a statement that unless the consumer, within thirty days after receipt of the notice, disputes the validity of the debt, or any portion thereof, the debt will be assumed to be valid by the debt collector ; ( 4 ) a statement that if the consumer notifies the debt collector in writing within the thirty-day period that the debt, or any portion thereof, is disputed, the debt collector will obtain verification of the debt or a copy of a judgment against the consumer and a copy of such verification or judgment will be mailed to the consumer by the debt collector ; and ( 5 ) a statement that, upon the consumers written request within the thirty-day period, the debt collector will provide the consumer with the name and address of the original creditor, if different from the current creditor.

( b ) Disputed debts If the consumer notifies the debt collector in writing within the thirty-day period described in subsection ( a ) that the debt, or any portion thereof, is disputed, or that the consumer requests the name and address of the original creditor, the debt collector shall cease collection of the debt, or any disputed portion thereof, until the debt collector obtains verification of the debt or a copy of a judgment, or the name and address of the original creditor, and a copy of such verification or judgment, or name and address of the original creditor, is mailed to the consumer by the debt collector. Collection activities and communications that do not otherwise violate this subchapter may continue during the 30-day period referred to in subsection ( a ) unless the consumer has notified the debt collector in writing that the debt, or any portion of the debt, is disputed or that the consumer requests the name and address of the original creditor. Any collection activities and communication during the 30-day period may not overshadow or be inconsistent with the disclosure of the consumers right to dispute the debt or request the name and address of the original creditor.

( c ) Admission of liability The failure of a consumer to dispute the validity of a debt under this section may not be construed by any court as an admission of liability by the consumer.

( d ) Legal pleadings A communication in the form of a formal pleading in a civil action shall not be treated as an initial communication for purposes of subsection ( a ).

( e ) Notice provisions The sending or delivery of any form or notice which does not relate to the collection of a debt and is expressly required by title 26, title V of Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act [ 15 U.S.C. 6801 et seq. ], or any provision of Federal or State law relating to notice of data security breach or privacy, or any regulation prescribed under any such provision of law, shall not be treated as an initial communication in connection with debt collection for purposes of this section.

When they send the email, it says the same in the email as it is on the website in regard to balance due. I've contacted them twice on this matter. They have blocked my card until I make the payment for this pay cycle due on the XXXX of XXXX. Subject : Dispute of Inaccurate Credit Report Information dear cfpb I am writing to formally dispute the inaccurate information on my credit report. Specifically, I am referring to a charge-off reported by MCA, which is over XXXX XXXX XXXX. This charge-off is significantly impacting my credit score and hindering my ability to secure housing. 

According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), negative information such as charge-offs should not be reported on a consumers credit report after 7 years from the date of first delinquency ( FCRA 605 ( a ) and ( b ) ) 1. The inclusion of this outdated charge-off is a violation of my rights under the FCRA. 

Furthermore, as a resident of XXXX XXXX, Washington, I am protected under the Washington Law Against Discrimination ( WLAD ) and the Fair Housing Act ( FHA ). These laws prohibit discrimination in housing based on disability and ensure that individuals with disabilities have equal access to housing opportunities23. The erroneous entry of this outdated charge-off on my credit report is hindering my fair chances of securing housing, which is a violation of these protections. 

This erroneous entry has detrimentally affected my credit score, dragging it below XXXX, and is severely limiting my opportunities to secure housing. As I am on a fixed income, receiving only XXXX, my ability to pay for housing is already constrained. The presence of this outdated charge-off further exacerbates my situation, making it nearly impossible to find fair housing. 

I kindly request that cfpb investigate this matter and remove the inaccurate charge-off from my credit report immediately. I do not remember owning any money to sound credit union and i was never contacted until recently by XXXX XXXX XXXX for owing any money until XXXX collection agency contacted me.below i have copy and pasted part of my credit report highlighting the disputed item, as well as a cease and desist request letter for XXXX as i felt their collection tactics were unethical and innapropriate. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. I look forward to your swift resolution of this issue.

So once I straightened this out on XXXX XXXX XXXX, they said they would refund the final money, clear my escrow account and reduce my payment to the original amount in XXXX business days, meaning at the end of XXXX. It has now been XXXX days since that phonecall and still I have no refund and my payment still includes the forced insurance amount. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
15 U.S. Code 1692c - Communication in connection with debt collection ( a ) CoMMUnication WitH tHe conSUMeR GeneRallY Without the prior consent of the consumer given directly to the debt collector or the express permission of a court of competent jurisdiction, a debt collector may not communicate with a consumer in connection with the collection of any debt ( c ) CeaSinG coMMUnication If a consumer notifies a debt collector in writing that the consumer refuses to pay a debt or that the consumer wishes the debt collector to cease further communication with the consumer, the debt collector shall not communicate further with the consumer with respect to such debt, except ( 1 ) to advise the consumer that the debt collectors further efforts are being terminated ; ( 2 ) to notify the consumer that the debt collector or creditor may invoke specified remedies which are ordinarily invoked by such debt collector or creditor ; or ( 3 ) where applicable, to notify the consumer that the debt collector or creditor intends to invoke a specified remedy.

If such notice from the consumer is made by mail, notification shall be complete upon receipt.

A debt collector may not engage in any conduct the natural consequence of which is to harass, oppress, or abuse any person in connection with the collection of a debt. Without limiting the general application of the foregoing, the following conduct is a violation of this section : ( 1 ) The use or threat of use of violence or other criminal means to harm the physical person, reputation, or property of any person.

( 2 ) The use of obscene or profane language or language the natural consequence of which is to abuse the hearer or reader.

( 3 ) The publication of a list of consumers who allegedly refuse to pay debts, except to a consumer reporting agency or to persons meeting the requirements of section 1681a ( f ) or 1681b ( 3 ) [ 1 ] of this title.

( 4 ) The advertisement for sale of any debt to coerce payment of the debt.

( 5 ) Causing a telephone to ring or engaging any person in telephone conversation repeatedly or continuously with intent to annoy, abuse, or harass any person at the called number.

( 6 ) Except as provided in section 1692b of this title, the placement of telephone calls without meaningful disclosure of the callers identity.

( Pub. L. 90321, title VIII, 806, as added Pub. L. 95109, Sept. 20, 1977, 91 Stat. 877. ) I have not supplied proof under the doctrine of estoppel by silence, Engelhardt v. Gravens ( mo ) 281 SW 715,719, I presume that no proof of the alleged debt, nor therefore any such debt, in fact therefor exists pursuant to 18 USC 8, L owe no debt, this company is violation my consumer right to privacy pursuant to 15 USC 1681-B2 company has no permission to report my information per 15 USC 16814 .
