Ordered a grant writing service from a female named XXXX XXXX who uses the name XXXX XXXX She didn't deliver on the service. She wasn't clear on the payment schedule and terms either. It was essentially theft by deception. XXXX agreed to a full refund and didn't make good on it like most scam artists. I was billed three times at {$36.00} for a total of {$100.00}. Chase has processed 2 of the 3 required refunds. This is not an oversight. Please provide the rightful refund.

Additionally you have the email from the merchant agreeing to a full refund.Any further delay is unreasonable and of Chase 's own error.

Product: Money transfer, virtual currency, or money service
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I received an email from XXXX XXXX of XXXX XXXX, with instructions and screencaps on how to set-up an auto-pay account with Alliance Bank ( see XXXX XXXX ). I cant recall the reason for the abrupt switch, but I honestly didnt care at the time. 

Approximately 5 years later, I received a certified mail with a demand letter from XXXX XXXX for fines and late fees totaling {$200.00}. I was completely dumbfounded, the main reason why I voluntarily signed up for auto-pay was to ensure that my assessments would be paid on time every month and late fees avoided. I had been receiving payment confirmation emails ( see XXXX  XXXX ) from Alliance Bank at the end of every month for approximately 5 years and there was nothing to indicate that anything was amiss. As a paperless household, I use auto-pay to help manage all of my bills. From my utilities to internet, I would basically set them all on auto-pay and be worry-free to focus on other things. Not once have I ever had a problem or issue with auto-pay until I started using Alliance Bank , solely at the behest of XXXX XXXX . We really didnt have a choice, if we wanted to use auto-pay, Alliance Bank was the only option available. 

According to XXXX XXXX, the late fees and subsequent fines were accrued whenever the HOA increased our monthly assessments and I failed to adjust my auto-pay accordingly to reflect the higher amount owed. They had explained that anytime the full amount is not received, its considered late and a fine would be assessed. I still didnt quite understand what the issue was since the balance for some of my other bills would fluctuate month-to-month and auto-pay has been working flawlessly for me. How is it possible to be setup on auto-pay and still accrue late fees at the same time? It was oxymoronic to me, so I decided to investigate and logged on to my account with Alliance to learn more. After the initial auto-pay setup that occurred 5 years earlier, I realized I had never logged back on because how often would anyone need to do that after setting up their auto-pay? After clicking on the XXXX link to the Alliance Bank web portal, I did not recognize the user interface and immediately needed a password reset to gain access to my account ( see XXXX  XXXX ). 

Once I was able to gain access, what I had discovered was really shocking and unlike any other auto-pay service I had ever used or witnessed ( XXXX  XXXX ). My first observation was the {$1.00} fee per ACH transaction, I have never been charged a fee to use auto-pay before. On top of that, this {$1.00} fee was never once mentioned nor disclosed in any of the screen caps from XXXX XXXX XXXX instructional email, nor do I recall ever being asked for my consent. 

Whats even more troubling was the verbiage right under the Fixed Amount box, a sentence and acknowledgement that I found to be highly unusual, impractical, and offensively intrusive to my financial privacy rights. It reads, You acknowledge and agree that your Association may update, however, is not required to updated your payment amount when a new assessment is assigned by the Association. As a grammatical sentence, its completely meaningless, incomprehensible, and misleading. Its only purpose was to inform the account holders that other people or the Association would have access and authority to change the auto-pay amount without their knowledge or consent. This is a completely outrageous, invasive, and patently ridiculous requirement of Alliance Bank for the use of its {$1.00} per payment auto-pay service. As the sole provider of the auto-pay service to homeowners at XXXX, Alliance Bank has a complete monopoly, courtesy of XXXX XXXX and potentially in violation of the United States antitrust laws. In exchange for this quid pro quo arrangement, Alliance Bank has given XXXX XXXX, veily disguised as the Association, unfettered access to its banking customers accounts without prior consent or proper authorization. 

Needless to say, I was livid and felt totally betrayed by Alliance Bank as a client and eventually decided to close my account. In an email exchange with XXXX XXXX, the HOA Support Specialist for Alliance Bank, about unauthorized access, he had indicated ( XXXX  XXXX ) that you logged youre your payment account on XX/XX/XXXX, but the ip address for that activity and specified date was inexplicably and conveniently omitted from their account log. Whereas my password reset request and activity back on XX/XX/XXXX, was logged with my home ip address, the activity back on XX/XX/XXXX was completed XXXX. I have requested proof of prior consent and even emailed associates of Alliance Bank many similar questions to XXXX XXXX. Their responses or a lack thereof, has been repetitive, evasive, and consistent all the way up to XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX  XXXX ). Please refer to your homeowners association appears to be the standing order and standard response for all Alliance Bank associates. The idea that our XXXX XXXX, a non-profit entity located in XXXX XXXX Texas, and its governing documents, would have direct impact, influence, and oversight of Alliance Bank operations is a concept beyond my limited comprehension. Does it also supersede federal banking laws, regulatory compliance, and jurisdiction of XXXX XXXX, Nevada? What does my HOA have to do with an ACH payment transaction conducted at a bank located approximately XXXX miles away in a different state and time zone? What happens if the Association used it XXXX  privileges to adjust the auto-pay amount to {$1000.00} on an account belonging to an XXXX  resident like my next-door neighbor, XXXX XXXX, who is XXXX XXXX XXXX and doesnt own a computer or tech savvy enough to uncover this gross invasion of privacy perpetrated by XXXX XXXX  in cooperation with Alliance Bank? How can we be certain that it hasnt happened already? 

When I later tried to log back on to my account, I learned that I had been placed on hold ( XXXX XXXX ). When I confronted Alliance Bank about my current status and reminded them of their complete monopoly over the auto-pay service for XXXX residents, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX the HOA Operations Manager , said, You do have the option to mail a check or by using your financial institutions XXXX XXXX ( XXXX  XXXX ). 

Following XXXX XXXX advice, I inconveniently mailed my assessment check to Alliance Bank well in advance of the XX/XX/XXXX due date but nevertheless, I was still assessed a late fee by XXXX XXXX. Learning from my earlier mistake that trust must be earned and not given, I brought the check, stamped envelope, and visited the nearest USPS post office. I asked XXXX XXXX XXXX to mail, sign and bear witness ( XXXX  XXXX ) to the check and letter being sent. Nevertheless, the outcome was the exactly the same and my check didnt clear until well over a month later ( XXXX  XXXX ), providing XXXX XXXX with the perfect opportunity to assess another late fee and fine to my account. Its either an unbelievable coincidence or Alliance Bank was intentionally withholding my check as retaliation for my actions and demand of accountability from XXXX XXXX, an Alliance Bank business partner and co-conspirator against commerce, market competition, and fair trade. Its no wonder why Alliance Bank has earned such high praise and rave reviews from XXXX XXXX ( XXXX  XXXX ). 

According to XXXX XXXX, Chief Operating Officer & Partner at XXXX XXXX XXXX, Alliance Association Bank does what they do better than anyone else because it is their true specialization. So, what exactly is it that Alliance Bank specializes in that gives it a competitive advantage over all of the other banks in Texas? Why would a property management company located in XXXX, Texas, force homeowners of the XXXX community located in XXXX XXXX, Texas, to send money and patronize a bank from the state of Nevada? Well, as it turns out, no other bank can intentionally manipulate the auto-pay option quite like Alliance Association Bank , a subsidiary of Western Alliance Bank , a reputable organization with a sterling reputation and well-established Code of Business Conduct and Ethics that all employees must agree to, as a condition for employment. 

When homeowners and/or consumers sign up for auto-pay, a vast majority of them use the Total New Balance option. Its not an insider secret and this option is practically synonymous with auto-pay. When you say auto-pay, it means paying the total balance or whatever amount is owed on a specific calendar day. No one signs up for auto-pay so he or she can periodically log back in to make adjustments, thats completely nonsensical and counter-intuitive to the whole concept of auto-pay. 

When you access the Alliance Bank portal to set-up a scheduled auto-pay, you will notice they only offer 2 convenient options for a fee of {$1.00} to XXXX homeowners. A one-time payment and a scheduled payment ( XXXX  XXXX ). The XXXX and most widely-used option of any auto-pay service has completely disappeared. Is this the illusion, magic trick, and specialization that XXXX XXXX was raving about? Well, spoiler alert, theres nothing special about deceptive business practices, thats why Texas has the Deceptive Trade Practices Act and the federal government has the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. If you simply scroll down to the bottom of the page ( XXXX  XXXX ) and click on the Online Payment Terms and Conditions, on the 2nd page of their 12-page pdf file titled ONLINE PAYMENT SERVICE END USER TERMS AND CONDITIONS, you will learn that Total New Balance is the 3rd option of their Scheduled Payment Program ( XXXX  XXXX ). Its very important to read the fine prints, I would highly recommend that Alliance Association Bank start with their own. 

Not only is this unethical, Alliance Association Bank is an active participant in a fraudulent scheme and racket against its own paying customers. By intentionally removing the 3rd and most important scheduled payment option, Alliance is creating the ideal condition and confounding environment for busy individuals and unsuspecting homeowners to mess up so XXXX XXXX will have the opportunity to assess its infamous {$25.00} late fees. Its helping to generate an additional revenue stream for XXXX XXXX that may or may not go back to the coffers of the XXXX XXXX, a Texas non-profit entity. Last I checked, XXXX XXXX and Alliance Association Bank are not 501 ( c ) organizations. 

Its not a coincidence for XXXX XXXX to choose a bank in Nevada to open an account for an HOA with an estimated annual budget of {$4.00} XXXX. Alliance Association Bank is located outside the jurisdiction of Texas state laws, district court orders, and well beyond the reach of our community governing documents aka covenant. Alliance Association Bank works with property management companies like XXXX XXXX, not HOAs, its a very important distinction. Our web portal link to the bank is XXXX not XXXX, so there should be no doubt about who has control of the XXXX XXXX bank account at Alliance Association Bank. If I were a betting man, I would have my money on XXXX XXXX XXXX, our former property manager and current property director, a position they mustve created just for her. I would be very surprised if any of the board members actually have access to the bank account as required by the covenant. For these reasons and more, I thought it was only appropriate to file this formal complaint with the CFPB and I hope a referral to US Attorneys Office and/or FBI field office to investigate this matter further will soon follow. Thank you, I look forward to your response and guidance.

Product: Money transfer, virtual currency, or money service
Consumer complaint narrative:
General Obligation : Between XX/XX/year>, I fell victim to XXXX multi-layered scam operations run by XXXX  which involved me making deposits for a total amount of XXXX XXXX  from my COINBASE account to fraudulent investment firm ( XXXX ). 
Page 2 of 5 2 When determining whats reasonable and fair, we should focus on the issue of liability ; common queries include, but are not limited to, the following ( i ) whether COINBASE did not take notice of any rule, law, or regulation, and/or possibly missed any material elements of the relevant bylaws or codes of conduct, that may have prevented them from protecting my financial safety ; ( ii ) whether by virtue of COINBASEs custodianship over my funds or by its control over them, they owed a fiduciary duty to the me and if so, whether that duty was breached ; ( iii ) whether COINBASE promoted the transaction ( s ) in question despite being aware of the nature of the transaction ( XXXX ) in question ( iv ) whether COINBASE was in compliance with its own policies and procedures ; ( v ) whether COINBASE owed duties to myself, what the scope of those duties was, and whether COINBASE did not uphold those duties ; ( vi ) whether COINBASEs conduct was unfair ; and ( XXXX ) whether COINBASE has XXXX its power the ability to, and should, compensate me for the harm that has befallen me. 
Upon identification of such unusual or suspicious activity, it is crucial that the relevant staff member adequately describe the factors making an activity or transaction suspicious, thoroughly depict the extent and nature of this activity and properly communicate to the customer that such activity meets the relevant criteria of fraud. 
In providing its services to a customer, a financial institution is required by law to exercise the care and skill of a diligent, prudent banker. In this case, this means that the payment service provider should not turn a blind eye to known facts pointing to a real possibility that their customer is being scammed. In other words, COINBASE must have had special knowledge of what was occurring or been alerted to a real possibility of fraud taking place. The financial institution must have known or reasonably ought to have known that I was dealing with a scammer. 
Granted, there is room for diversity of view insofar as reasonableness is concerned. Indeed, there is a sense in which the standard of care of the reasonable person involves in its application a subjective element. 
However, it must be remembered that the correct test is always reasonable care in all circumstances, not average care. The fact that most people behave in a certain way may be good evidence that the conduct is reasonable, but this is not necessarily the case. Although reasonableness is a very fluid concept, all of the evidence suggests that COINBASE did not foresee the fraud and disregarded even the most obvious dangers in this respect. 
Situations do tend to repeat themselves and it is advisable to examine previous outcomes to see how the standard of the reasonable person should be applied, and that lessons can be learnt from the errors of the past. 
Refuting COINBASEs

Product: Checking or savings account
Sub-issue: Problem with renewal
Consumer complaint narrative:
I opened a XXXX CD for {$XXXX} with Synchrony Bank XXXX XX/XX/year>, knowing that I would need the money at the end of the term. I did not realize and do not recall being informed that the XXXX  would be automatically renewed at the end of the term. Synchrony Bank automatically renewed the XXXX  at the end of the XXXX  months without my permission, and when I learned this after the fact and contacted them, they refused to end the new term and let me withdraw the money ( not including interest earned from the new term -- I am totally fine to forfeit that ). After finding that I couldn't do anything about it on their website, an online chat with customer service, and two phone calls with customer service in which I was given the runaround about unrelated issues, a manager told me on the phone that there was no way they could close the XXXX  without a mandatory penalty of 6 months interest -- or more than XXXX of the money I had earned from the first 14 month term. So my money is stuck with them for another 14 months or I have to pay $ XXXX in penalty. 

It is important to note that I live in XXXX on a XXXX XXXX XXXX as a civil servant ( I have been here XXXX years now ), which is one reason I received the notice that the XXXX  had been renewed so late and may have also contributed to problems I experienced when trying to use their website, though I have generally been able to use all other financial institutions ' websites with no problem here. 

Here are the other problems I experienced with Synchrony Bank : 1 ) I couldn't access their website to check on the account several months before it matured, even after calling technical support for help and spending a long time on the phone trying different things. 2 ) It wasn't clear to me when I established the XXXX  that it would automatically renew if I didn't take action. 3 ) Synchrony Bank sent me emails saying I had a message from them and wanted me to log on to their site to see what the message was instead of clearly informing me what was about to happen. This was after I had had problems with their website, and I didn't log on. 4 ) The only paper notice that I know I received arrived weeks after the XXXX  had already renewed and the 7 (? ) day " grace period '' had already expired. I called within 24-48 hours of receiving the letter, and they would not let me close the account without a large penalty. As far as I can tell, I never received a paper notification beforehand saying the XXXX  would automatically renew. 5 ) Synchony still won't let me provide instructions now to automatically withdraw the money at the end of the new XXXX  term. They told me it is impossible to do that now and said I must call them within 45 days of the end of the new term to give them my instructions.

Taken together, this is absolutely unacceptable treatment. And when I called and offered a very reasonable solution ( offering them several more weeks to get the money back to me and letting them keep two months interest from the new term ), they did nothing to help resolve the problem and instead made me jump through hoops to even discuss the problems I was experiencing. I believe Synchrony is also using deceptive business practices.

At XXXX XXXX he text messaged me and told me he was XXXX minutes away. At XXXX XXXX, I texted him but there was no answer from that point on. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Their investigation did not fix an error on your report
Consumer complaint narrative:
NOTICE TO AGENT IS NOTICE TO PRINCIPAL NOTICE TO PRINCAL IS NOTICE TO AGENT You Santander Consumer USA are furnishing inaccurate and incorrect information to the consumer reporting agencies. 

The reporting of such inaccurate information has caused severe damage to my character, my reputation, my general mode of living and my ability to obtain credit for personal and house purposes. 

You and your inaccurate reporting have damaged my livelihood. 

15 U.S. Code 16815-2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( A ) Reporting information with actual knowledge of errors A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. 

Duty : a moral or legal obligation ; a responsibility Accurate : correct in all details ; exact. 

PROHIBITION : a law or regulation forbidding something As Defined by The IRS Even if you didn't receive a Form 1099-C, you must report canceled debt as gross income on your tax return. 

The IRS Clearly defines a charge off as Gross or Ordinary income, INCOME DOES NOT GET REPORTED ON THE CONSUMER REPORT which in fact makes your reporting of this account inaccurate. 

By Definition The IRS Clearly says a Cancelled or Charge off is Income. The reporting of this account as a debt is in accurate. 

15 USC 1681 s-2 Says you Santander Consumer USA are a furnisher of information to a consumer reporting agency. 

You ARE PROHIBITED BY LAW to furnish inaccurate information. I demand you to cease and Desist the reporting of incorrect in accurate information immediately. 

15 USC 1681 5-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate You are hereby put on NOTICE that you are furnishing incorrect inaccurate information. 
The lender must file Form 1099-C and send you a copy if the amount of debt canceled is {$600.00} or more and the lender is a financial institution, credit union , federal government agency, or other applicable entity as discussed earlier in chapter 1.

The above paragraph is taken directly from the IRS 2024 publication. 

SEND ME MY FORM 1099-C that you should have sent when you filled the account as a canceled debt. 

15 U.S. Code 16815-2 ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if- A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if- ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate ; and ( il ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate. 

In conclusion I have shown you and you have been put on notice that you are reporting inaccurate information. 

The information is, in fact, inaccurate. 

The continued reporting of this inaccurate information is a clear violation of the Law 15 USC 1681 s-2 of your responsibilities as a furnisher of information.

You have caused me and my family severe harm due to your negligence and inaccurate reporting. This is a final opportunity to Cure and DELETE This Erroneous, inaccurate account from my Consumer report. 

YOU HAVE 10 Calendar days to DELETE THIS ACCOUNT FROM MY CONSUMER REPORTS! 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX GA XXXX

Product: Credit card
Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative: On Monday, XX/XX/XXXX at XXXX I purchased a pair of {$600.00} XXXX  XXXX ( discounted to {$180.00} pre-tax ) from XXXX using PayPal 's Pay-in-4 split pay feature, using my XXXX XXXX as the funding payment method. I placed my order and went about my day. The next day, Tuesday XX/XX/XXXX, my order shipped via XXXX. The XXXX tracking number provided was XXXX. The package was picked up by XXXX on Tuesday, XX/XX/XXXX, and was out for delivery Wednesday, XX/XX/XXXX, at XXXXXXXX XXXX The package was delivered at XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX without any kind of signature confirmation required. I was at work all day, but I was aware that a delivery had happened. At about XXXX XXXX., an unknown person was let into the apartment building by a neighbor who was exiting for a smoke. This man went to the 5th floor via the elevator and then walked down to the 4th floor from the 5th floor, appearing to be scanning the area. for packages. He went down to the third floor, and then made his way to the second floor where I live and he located my package. On my XXXX  camera, as well as on multiple different high quality cameras that the building was kind enough to provide me with, he was caught on camera taking the package into the staircase between the second and first floor, opening the package and removing my items, and then disposing of the shipping box in the third floor trash room. He then left the building. I was not aware that a theft had occurred until I returned back home from work around XXXX XXXX that day. When I noticed that there was no package in front of my door nor in the lobby by the mailboxes, I immediately opened my XXXX  camera and looked to see if there was anything abnormal. I then found footage of the theft. I called the local police precinct to ask them what I should do and they informed me to call XXXX  and to file a police report with officers. I did so. After compiling the video footage from my own XXXX camera as well as from the building, alongside the official police report, I reached out to XXXX the same night as the theft. I spoke to somebody on the phone and explained the situation, and a claim was opened with XXXX  to investigate further steps. I was under the impression by the agent I spoke with that I would be protected by XXXX because I had not received my order and this was not my fault. I had even asked the representative what would happen if the claim was denied by XXXX  to which I was told, " don't worry, XXXX will take care of you.. From then on, I was not too concerned. The next day, a detective from the XXXX visited my apartment while I was at work. We spoke over the phone since I was not there to answer the door for him. We discussed the events that happened and I provided him with all of the footage I received, which he then had added to my police report filing. I was informed that facial recognition is going to be run on the thief, since we had such high quality video including multiple full-face angles. I continued to not be too concerned because I was under the impression that I was protected financially for this loss by either the merchant, the payment processor or my credit card company. Later on that evening of Friday the XXXX, I received an email from XXXX informing me that the claim was rejected by XXXX due to the package showing as delivered and that XXXX was refusing to take responsibility for the stolen package. I was shocked to read this, so I reached out to PayPal where I made my purchase through knowing they had buyer protection. I explained the situation and was met with very similar verbiage that they will not be responsible for a package being stolen. I was baffled that their buyer protection policy, that specifically states if you did not receive your purchase, you will be protected and issued a refund. I was very shocked to hear that PayPal 's buyer protection did not have my back as they have advertised. I reached out to XXXX, who was the funding card for my split pay plan, and was met with the same answer. I called XXXX again and was told the same thing. I was told to continue working with law enforcement, which I am, however I am confused how buyer protection for not receiving your order does not apply to a theft that was very much not in ones control. I do not live in a single family home where someone can just walk up to a porch and walk away with a package, this thief trespassed on the property and I was not home or able to protect myself or the package from the theft. I am currently out exactly {$190.00}. The investigation is still ongoing with the XXXX for the theft, although I am less confident of a positive outcome, as I have seen the responses I received from the merchant, payment processor, and credit card company essentially blaming me for being robbed. What I am seeking is financial relief in the amount of my purchase price from some kind of consumer protection insurance clause that will protect me from this unforeseeable financial loss that was well beyond my reasonable control.

Consumer complaint narrative:
I am filing this complaint to inform you that GM Financial has unlawfully reported an unauthorized inquiry on my XXXX consumer report. I have not given permission for GM Financial to access my consumer report, and there is no permissible purpose by law for this inquiry. I am a victim of identity theft. I have filed an identity theft report with my local police department and the FTC. ( see Evidence ) I have not initiated any transaction with GM FINANCIAL. Furthermore, I do not have an account as defined under 15 U.S.C. 1693a ( 2 ) with GM FINANCIAL for review or collection. I wrote to GM Financial on XX/XX/XXXX [ certified mail # XXXX ] and again on XX/XX/XXXX [ certified mail # XXXX ] to resolve these issues to no avail ( See Evidence ). I have requested the general or specific certifications pursuant to Rule 1002 required by 15 U.S.C. 1681b ( f ) ( 2 ) to establish permissible purpose and they have provided no such documentation. 

Details of Violation : Dates of Unauthorized Inquiry : XX/XX/XXXX Consumer Reporting Agency : XXXX ( XXXX violation ) By obtaining my consumer report on the aforementioned date without any permissible purpose, GM Financial is in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), codified at 15 U.S.C 1681b ( a ) 3 ( f ) ( i ), 15 U.S.C. 1681b ( f ) ( 2 ) ,15 U.S.C. 1681e ( a ). Therefore, GM Financial has committed 15 U.S.C. 1681q, which is tantamount to 18 U.S.C. 1028A. This statute invokes 15 U.S.C. 1681n ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ), and I am owed remedy per violation. 

References : Case Law : XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXX ) XXXX XXXX : section XXXX of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act ( 15 U.S.C. 6823 ) ( relating to obtaining customer information by false pretenses ) ; 15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( a ) ( 8 ) ( E ) 15 U.S.C. 1681i 15 U.S.C. 1681b ( f ) 15 U.S.C. 1681n ( a ) ( 1 ) ( B ) Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection Advisory Opinion : 12 CFR Part 1022, Fair Credit Reporting ; Permissible Purposes for Furnishing, Using, and Obtaining Consumer Reports. 


Statutes Violated : 15 U.S.C. 1681b ( f ) ( 2 ) 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( a ) 15 U.S.C. 1681b ( a ) 3 ( f ) ( i ) 15 U.S.C. 1681q 18 U.S.C. 1028A

Details of the Violation : Creditor : XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX : {$38000.00} Collection Agency : Sarma Collections , Inc . 
Account Number : XXXX Description of the Violation : Sarma Collections , Inc. has engaged in practices that violate USC 1692c , which governs communication in connection with debt collection. Specifically, they have : Communicated with me at an inconvenient time or place, despite being informed that such communication is not acceptable. 

Continued communication after receiving written notice that I refuse to pay the debt or wish to cease further communication. 

Disclosed information about my debt to third parties without my consent.

Product: Debt collection
Sub-issue: Attempted to collect wrong amount
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of Collection Attempt for Repossessed Vehicle I am writing to dispute the collection attempts made by your company regarding the outstanding balance on the vehicle that was repossessed and subsequently sold. The harassing nature of your collection attempts is causing me undue stress and XXXX. 

It has come to my attention that the vehicle in question was repossessed and sold by your company. According to my understanding of the laws governing such situations, the proceeds from the sale of the repossessed vehicle should be used to offset the outstanding balance on the loan. Any remaining amount, known as the deficiency balance, is what the borrower is typically responsible for paying. 

I request that you provide me with a detailed breakdown of the sale of the vehicle, including the sale price, any associated fees, and the calculation of the remaining balance. I believe that the amount you are currently attempting to collect from me does not accurately reflect the deficiency balance after the sale of the vehicle. 

Furthermore, I would like to bring to your attention that the constant communication and pressure from your company constitute harassment under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). I respectfully request that you cease all communication with me until this matter is resolved appropriately. 

Please provide me with the necessary documentation to support your claim for the full amount and an explanation for the discrepancy between the sale price of the vehicle and the amount you are attempting to collect from me. 

I expect a prompt response within [ specify a reasonable timeframe ] days of receiving this letter. Failure to provide the requested information may result in further action on my part to protect my rights as a consumer. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to resolving this dispute in a fair and amicable manner. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Company: Larry H. Miller Group of Companies

Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/year>, I ordered a table from XXXX XXXX that was advertised as ready to ship. After XXXX weeks with no shipment, I contacted XXXX XXXX, and they informed me that it would be several months before the table would be available. I decided to cancel my order and notified Affirm, through XXXX XXXX, about the cancellation. Affirm instructed me to wait for XXXX XXXX to process the refund. 

At the end of XXXX, I received an email from XXXX XXXX confirming the cancellation and stating that I would be refunded within 10 business days. However, the refund did not arrive. I then opened a dispute on the XXXX XXXX app, but continued to receive non-payment notifications. When I called Affirm, they suggested opening a dispute but consistently failed to follow through. Despite my efforts to resolve the issue, including forwarding over 15 emails from XXXX XXXX, Affirm claimed they did not receive these emails and suggested I reach out to XXXX XXXX directly. 

Throughout this process, I was advised to continue making payments to avoid affecting my credit score. However, despite my clear communication that I wanted to resolve the issue and avoid credit damage, Affirm did not formally open a dispute. Consequently, they reported the issue to the credit bureaus, which severely impacted my credit score. 

This unresolved situation has placed an undue financial burden on me, hindering my ability to secure a mortgage at a reasonable rate. After exhausting all efforts to resolve the matter, I eventually paid the total amount. I have since filed a complaint with the Ohio Attorney Generals office, yet I have still not received a refund from either XXXX XXXX or Affirm, and the issue remains on my credit report.
